This is Palmira’s fourth loan with Hluvuku (Kiva’s Field Partner) and her first with Kiva. She used the first two loans (of 6,000MTn and 10,000MTn respectively) to purchase construction materials and the third loan (of 10,000MTn) to buy a freezer. She intends to use this loan in the amount of 12,000MTn to continue buying construction materials. Her greatest dream is to finish her studies to improve her salary.

Translated from Portuguese by April Newman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr: M.W. est une boutiquier installe dans le quartier de guediawaye depuis pluisieurs annees. Il vend en detail des produits divers et parvient a ecouler facilement ses marchandises. mais il fait face a une forte demande qu il compte satisfaire avec ce credit
texts.en:
Mr. W. has been a shopkeeper in the Guediawaye quarter (Dakar Region) for several years. He retails various items and has no problem selling his stock, but he experiences high customer demand that he intends to meet with this loan.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster his stock

loans.name: Teresa Helena

texts.pt:
Teresa Helena P. natural de Maputo, tem 35 anos de idade casada maritalmente e mãe de 2 filhos com idade de 15 anos o primeiro e 13 anos  o segundo, para alem dos seus filhos sustenta seus irmãos e sua mãe que vive com eles.

Teresa estudou ate 7ªclasse antes do seu casamento e depois continuou e neste momento frequenta 10ªclasse período nocturno, ela cresceu juntos do pais aos 7 anos começou a estudar e aos 19 anos se juntou. Tem casa própria.

Teresa vive basicamente de negocio tendo um estabelecimento comercial desde 2004 e abre das 7:00h e fecha as 20:30h, tem como melhor produto os refrigerantes onde vende a media de cerveja por 25 meticais e 15 o refresco. Tem um rendimento mensal de 4000,00mt.

Este para Teresa constitui o terceiro empréstimo na Hluvuku e segundo  no Kiva nunca solicitou noutras instituições. Com este empréstimo de 20000,00mt pretende aumentar o volume de vendas.

Para Teresa constitui grande sonho a transformação do pequeno estabelecimento em uma grande mercearia e tornar se grande empresaria e este conta com apoio de credito para a sua concretização.
texts.en:
Teresa Helena P. was born in Maputo, is 35 years old, married, and mother of two children. Her oldest is 15 years old and the second is 13. Besides her children, Teresa supports her siblings and her mother, who lives with them.

Teresa studied until the 7th grade, when she got married. She later decided to continue and is currently in the 10th grade, in night school. Teresa grew up with her parents, began school at the age of 7, and got married at 19. She has her own house.

Teresa essentially lives from her business establishment, which she has had since 2004. She opens at 7:00 a.m. and closes at 8:30 p.m. Her best-selling products are bottled drinks. She sells, on average, beer for 25 meticais and soft drinks for 15. Her monthly income is 4000.00 mt.

This is Teresa's third loan with Hluvuku and her second with Kiva. She has never sought loans at other institutions. She plans on increasing her sales volume with this loan of 20,000.00 mt.

It is Teresa's dream to transform her small establishment into a large general store and become a great business woman. To make her dream concrete, she counts on credit support


Translated from Portuguese by Jill Haring, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase sales volume in her business

loans.name: Margarida

texts.pt:
Margarida M. nasceu em Chibuto província de Gaza ao sul de Moçambique, tem 49 anos de idade, casada maritalmente e mãe de 4 filhos com idade entre 28, 27, 22 e 21 anos respectivamente, todos ainda estudantes. Os dois primeiros empregados e vive nas sua própria casas. Para alem dos seus filhos sustenta a sua mãe enviando produtos alimentícios quando poder. Neste momento vive numa casa própria. 

Margarida cresceu junto dos pais e mudou se da província de Gaza para Maputo para continuar com os estudos seguindo a carreira de medicina geral e assim quando chega na cidade de Maputo foi obrigada a incorporar se no serviço militar obrigatório tendo ido a Tanzânia no centro de preparação militar e assim nunca conseguiu continuar com os estudos tendo termina com a 10ªclasse.

Margarida é secretaria do Director da escola Militar da marinha de Guerra funcionaria permanente desde  1978. tem um horário das 7:30 as 15:30h, tem um salário mensal de 3624,00mt e consegue poupar 1000,00mt por mes.

Para margarida este é o seu primeiro empréstimo na Hluvuku e no Kiva, pretende com este valor comprar material de construção para melhorar a sua casa, e conheceu a Hluvuku através de conversas com os colegas que ja eram clientes e tem como planos futuros melhorar a sua cozinha em mobiliário.
texts.en:
Margarida M. was born in Chibuto in the province of Gaza, in southern Mozambique. She is 49 years old, married, and mother of 4 children aged 28, 27, 22, and 21 respectively. All of them are students. The first two are employed and live in their own homes. Besides her children, Margarida supports her mother by sending her food supplies when she can. She currently lives in her own house.

Margarida grew up with her parents, and moved from the province of Gaza to Maputo in order to continue her studies for a career in general medicine. However, when she arrived in the city of Maputo she was forced to join the mandatory military service, and went to the military preparation center in Tanzania. She, therefore, wasn't able to continue her studies after 10th grade.

Margarida is the secretary to the Director of the Military school of the War marines. She has been a permanent employee since 1978. She works from 7:30 a.m. to 3:30 pm. Her monthly salary is 3,624.00 mt, and she is able to save 1,000.00 mt each month.

This is Margarida's first loan with Hluvuku and Kiva. She intends to purchase construction material to improve her home with this money. She found out about Hluvuku through conversations with co-workers that were already clients. Her future plans are to improve her kitchen furniture.

Translated from Portuguese by Jill Haring, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials

loans.name: Judite Andrade

texts.pt:
Judite Andrade T. nasceu na província de Gaza ao sul de Moçambique, tem 47 anos de idade é separada e mãe de 2 filhos como idade de 25 e 23 anos respectivamente. Ambos ainda estudante, para alem dos seus filhos sustenta dois sobrinhos enviando dinheiro mensalmente.

Judite estudou ate 9ªclasse e parou por falta de condições, cresceu com a mãe mudou se de Gaza para Maputo quando tinha apenas dois anos quando os pais se separaram por um tempo teve que viver em casa da sua tia e ai a vida foi muito difícil razão que lhe fez abandonar cada vez mais os estudos, aos 21 anos se casou,

Judite é funcionaria como chefe dos recursos humanos a 3 anos, tem um horário das 7:30 ate 15:30h, tem um salário mensal de 4831,00mt e consegue poupar algum mensalmente. Diz que para alem deste salário tem outros susbsidios.

Este é o segundo empréstimo da Judite na Hluvuku e primeiro no Kiva, ja tem  no BIM banco internacional de Moçambique mas o sistema nao lhe agradou principalmente o período que concede. Constitui sonho criar uma empresa de prestação de serviços de ornamentação.
texts.en:
Judite Andrade T. was born in Gaza province in southern Mozambique. She is 47 years old, separated, and the mother of two. Her children are 23 and 25 years old and both students. In addition to supporting her children, she sends money to two nephews on a monthly basis.

Judite grew up with her mother and moved from Gaza to Maputo when she was only two years old. When her parents separated for a while she had to live with her aunt. Life was very hard, and bit by bit she had to abandon her studies. She got married when she was 21 years old.

Judite has been a human resources boss for three years and works from 7:30am to 3:30pm. Her monthly salary is 4831 meticais, and she is able to save some each month. She said that she has other forms of assistance in addition to this salary.

This is Judite’s second loan with Hluvuku (Kiva’s Field Partner) and her first with Kiva. She has had a loan with BIM (International Bank of Mozambique), but did not like the system, primarily the length of the loan term. Her dream is to open a decorating business.

Translated from Portuguese by April Newman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials

loans.name: Marcela Guilherme

texts.pt:
Marcela Guilherme C. é natural de Maputo e tem 26 anos de idade, casada maritalmente e mãe de 3 filhos com idade entre 8, 5 e 2 anos respectivamente, sendo que a maior estuda na 3ªclasse. Assim sustenta apenas 4 pessoas. Vive numa casa própria.

Marcela estudou até 7ªclasse e não continuou por falta de condições para custear os estudos. Nasceu e viveu com os pais e aos 8 anos divorciaram e ela teve que viver com a madrasta e assim a vida lhe foi muito difícil muito cedo tive que dedicar se ao negocio para sustentar se.

Marcela é negociante tem um estabelecimento comercial a mais de 8 anos, tem dois empregados e abre das 8:00 às 19:00h, aprendeu a fazer este trabalho num salão de Cabeleireiro como empregada durante dois anos. Para alem de venda de produtos de Beleza e serviços vende produtos de primeira necessidade onde destaca o amendoim que vende o copito por 10,00mt cada onde um quilo cabe 5 copitos.

Marcela tem um rendimento diário de 1500,00mt e poupa mensalmente 5000,00mt. Este é o primeiro empréstimo na Hluvuku e conheceu a Hluvuku através de conversa com amigas que já eram clientes. O seu Maio sonho é ter uma viatura para facilitar o seu negocio nas compras e vendas.
texts.en:
Marcela Guilherme C. is a native of Maputo. She is 26 years old, married, and the mother of three. The children are 2, 5, and 8 years old, and the oldest is in third grade. Marcela supports four people and lives in her own house.

Marcela studied through 7th grade and then did not continue because she could not afford to pay for her studies. She was born and raised by her parents for 8 years, at which point they got divorced and she had to live with her stepmother. Live became very hard; very early on she had to work to provide for herself.

Marcela has been in business for more than 8 years, and she has two employees. Her salon is open from 8am to 7pm. She learned this trade by being a hair salon employee for two years. In addition to selling beauty products and services, she sells some basic necessities. Among these, peanuts sales are big; she sells them for 10 meticais (MZN) per cup (five cups make up one kilogram).

Marcela makes 1,500 MZN per day and saves 5,000 MZN per month. This is her first loan from Hluvuku (Kiva’s Field Partner). She learned about Hluvuku by talking with friends who were already clients. Her big dream is to have a vehicle to facilitate buying and selling supplies for her business.

Translated from Portuguese by April Newman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase stock for her salon

loans.name: Leopoldina Da Carmeni

texts.pt:
Leopoldina tem34 ano, nasceu em Inhambane e cresceu na Matola. Ela é viuva e mãe de 4filhos com idades compriendida entre 15anos á 6meses, só o primeiro vai a escala porque o segundo é mudo e em Namaacha nào tem escola para crianças especiais.Leopoldina  e a sua familia  se mudaram para Namaacha uma vila na fronteira com Swazilândia  em 1996  quando o marido trabalhava na Fronteira com guarda-fronteira.

Leopoldina estudou apenas até 8ªclase e a única forma de ganhar avida para ela era entrar no mundo dos negócios. Em 1998 abriu um salão de cabeleleiro na sua propria residência uma vez que já tinha trabalhado como cabeleleira na sua infancia, teve bons resultados, mas 2006 o marido fica doente e ela teve que gastar todo fundo no tratamento da doença do marido que não resistiu  e  merdeu a vida em 2007. Apois essa desgraça leopoldida  ficou sem dinheiro para continuar com o seu negócio, com  3fihos para criar e gravida de 6meses só contava com ajuda do seu Pai. Três mêses depois ela  recebeu uma indemnização no serviço do marido e preferiu deixar na conta a prazo para os filhos porque para alem da quele valor começou a receber uma pensão mensal de 2,000.00mt. Com ajuda da hluvuku leopoldina transformou o antigo salão numa barraca onde vende produtos de primeira nessecidade, tem bons resultados conseque criar seus filhos e consegue poupar os 2,000.00mtn.
 
Este é o segundo emprestimo dela com Hluvuku e o primeiro com Kiva. O primeiro de 15,000.00mtn foram usados na compra de produtos para sua barraca e este segundo de 25,000.00mtn seram usados para mesmo fim. Pretende futuramente pedir outros emprestimos para investir no negócio de criação e venda de  frangos. Na foto Leopodina esta com seu filho.
texts.en:
Leopoldina is 34 years old, was born in Inhambane, and grew up in Matola. She is a widow and mother of four children, between 6 months and 15 years old. Only the oldest attends school because the second-oldest is mute, and there are no schools for children with special needs in Namaacha. Leopoldina and her family moved to Namaacha, a village on the border of Swaziland, in 1996 when her husband worked there as a border guard.

Leopoldina studied through only 8th grade, and the sole way for her to earn a living was to enter the workforce. Having worked as a barber in her youth, in 1998 she opened a hair salon in her home and was successful. In 2006, however, her husband became sick, and she had to spend all their money to treat him. He did not withstand the illness and lost his life in 2007. After this tragedy, Leopoldina had no money to continue her business. With three children to raise and six months pregnant, she counted on just her father’s help. Three months later she received an indemnity/benefit payment for her husband’s service. For her children, she opted to leave the funds in the account for the length of the term because in addition to the original amount, she began to receive a monthly pension of 2,000 meticais (MTn). With the help of Hluvuku (Kiva’s Field Partner), Leopoldina transformed the old salon into a shop where she sells basic necessities. She has had positive results and is able to raise her children and to save 2,000 MTn.

This is her second loan with Hluvuku and her first with Kiva. She used the first loan of 15,000 MTn to buy products for her shop, and will use this second loan of 25,000 MTn to do the same. In the future she intends to ask for more loans to invest in a chicken-selling business. In the photo Leopoldina appears with her son.

Translated from Portuguese by April Newman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase stock in her shop

loans.name: Lourenço Rafael

texts.pt:
Lourenço Rafael V. tem 26anos , nasceu e cresceu em Inhambane. É separado e pai de três filhos: um rapaz de 7anos e o mais novo com 1ano, somente o primeiro vive com ele.Mudou-se para Namaacha uma vila na fronteira com swazilândia a procura de emprego na companhia do seu primo.
Lourenço não teve a opurtunidade de ir a escola porque a seu pai era alcolico e ele como é o primeiro filho tinha que trabalhar nes machambas para alimentar os irmãos. Oas 13anos de idade sai de Inhambane para Namaacha em casa do seu primo onde trabalhou como domestico durante dois anos e ouferia mensalmente um valor de 350.00mtn.Depois trabalhou durante 4 meses como criador de frongos com o Sr Tnga um grande criador de frangos em Namaacha e recebia mensaolmente 400.00mtn. Em 1998 começa a praticar o seu proprio negócio com o fundo colectado nos seus 2anos e 4meses de trabalho,vende bolos, pães e creditos de recargas de mcel e vodacom na fronteira ( maputo/Swazilândia), o seu melhor produto são as recargas que compra por 15,00mtn, 45.00mtn, 74.00mtn e  90.00mtn e vende por 20.00mtn, 50.00mtn, 80.00mtn e 100.00mtn consecutivamente, tem um rendimento mensal de 4,000.00mtn e consegui poupar 1,000.00mtn mensalmente. Com a pratica do negócio Lourenço desenvolveu muito, conseguiu construir uma casa de alvenaria tipo três e esta a construir  autra casa uma vez que está para se casar  e não quer viver com a nova esposa na casa que construiu na companhia da sua ex esposa que se separou por esta ter contraido uma doença mantal a dois anos atrás.
Este é o segundo emprestimo de Louren,co na hluvuku e o primeiro com Kiva, o primeiro de 10.000.00mtn foram usados na compra de produtos para revenda uma vez que  o seu fundo era insuficiente devido a doença da ex esposa. Conseguiu recuperar e reembolsou antes do prazo determinado. Este segundo de 25,000.00mtn serão usados para mesmo fim e está confiante que vai conseguir pagar e pedir mais emprestimo para construir capueiras na sua residencia e fazer criação e fenda de frangos.
texts.en:
Lourenço Rafael V. is 26 years old and was born and raised in Inhambane. He is separated and the father of three children, between 1 and 7 years old. Only the oldest son lives with him. He moved to Namaacha, a village on the border of Swaziland, in search for work at his cousin’s company.

Lourenço did not have the opportunity to go to school because his father was an alcoholic, and being the oldest child Lourenço had to work on ranches to feed his siblings. When he was 13 years old, he left Inhambane for his cousin’s house in Namaacha, where he worked as a domestic servant for two years and earned 350 meticais (MTn) per month. Then he worked for four months raising chickens for Mr. Tnga, a major chicken farmer in Namaacha, and received 400 MTn per month. In 1998 he started his own business with the money he had saved from his two years and four months of work. He sells cakes, bread, and mcel and Vodacom phone cards on the border (between Maputo and Swaziland). His best products are the phone cards of 15, 45, 74, and 90 MTn, which he sells for 20, 50, 80, and 100 MTn respectively. He makes 4,000 MTn monthly and is able to save 1,000 MTn per month. From his work experience Lourenço has developed a lot. He was able to build a brick townhouse and will build another house when he is no longer married. He does not want to live with a new wife in the house he built with his ex-wife with whom he is separated because she contracted a mental disease two years ago.

This is Lourenço’s second loan with Hluvuku (Kiva’s Field Partner) and his first with Kiva. He used the first loan of 10,000 MTn to buy products to resell when he had insufficient funds, on account of his wife’s illness. He recuperated costs and repaid the loan before the due date. He will use this second loan of 25,000 MTn for the same purpose. He is confident that he will be able to repay it and will request another loan to build chicken coops at his house and to raise and sell chickens.

Translated from Portuguese by April Newman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase stock for his kiosk

loans.name: Alzira Rosa

texts.pt:
Alzira Rosa Z. é natural de Maputo, casada maritalmente e mãe de 5 filhos com idades entre 18, 13, 12, 8 e 6 anos respectivamente, para alem dos seus filhos sustenta uma nora que vive com ela.

Alzira estudou até 9ªclasse e não continuou por ter estado doente, ela cresceu junto dos seu pais e para alem de estudar  aprendeu a costura onde diz que fazia roupas de crianças actividade que veio a parar quando se casou em 1989, neste momento vive numa casa própria.

Alzira vive basicamente de negocio onde aluga  um estabelecimento comercial a 3 anos, o qual  abre das 7:00 e fechas as 21:00h todos os dias tem uma empregada, aprendeu a exercer esta actividade através do seu sogro que é grande comerciante tendo vários estabelecimentos comerciais na cidade de Maputo.

O estabelecimento dispõe de vários produtos em destaque os da primeira necessidade e os que tem mais rendimentos são os refrigerantes e Cervejas no qual vende a media de cerveja 25,00mt e 10,00mt o refrigerante. Tem um rendimento diário que varia de 500,00mt a 1500,00mt e consegue poupar algum mensalmente.

Para Alzira este é o primeiro empréstimo na Hluvuku e no Kiva, e já teve noutros bancos no valor de 5500,00mt valor que iniciou o negocio. Assim pretende com este valor aumentar os produtos existente para ter mais rendimentos. Constitui seu maior sonho construir seu próprio estabelecimento comercial.
texts.en:
Alzira Rosa Z. is a native of Maputo, married, and mother of 5 children: 6, 8, 12, 13, and 18 years old. In addition to her children, she supports a daughter-in-law who lives with her.

Alzira grew up with her parents. She studied through 9th grade and then discontinued her studies because she fell ill. Besides going to school, she also learned how to sew. She used to make children’s clothes, an activity which she stopped when she got married in 1989. Now she lives in her own house.

Alzira has been living basically off a business, renting out a commercial space, for three years. Her store opens at 7:00am and closes at 9:00pm everyday. She employs one woman. She learned this business activity from her father-in-law, who is a major businessperson who has several commercial enterprises in the city of Maputo.

The store provides a variety of products, mostly basic groceries. The highest-margin products are sodas and beer, which she sells for an average of 25 meticais (MTn) per beer and 10MTn per soda. Her daily sales range from 500MTn to 1500MTn, and she manages to save some money each month.

This is Alzira’s first loan with Hluvuku (Kiva’s Field Partner) and with Kiva. Previously she took out loans from other banks in the amount of 5500MTn to start her business. Now she plans to use this loan to increase her product offerings in order to increase her profits. Her greatest dream is to build her own commercial space.

Translated from Portuguese by April Newman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase inventory for her shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in products for her small beauty salon

loans.name: Shyam Kumari

texts.en: Shyam Kumari M. is from a small village in Khokhana, Latipur, where most of her neighbours are farmers.  Shyam  is married and has one son and one day, who both study in lower secondary school.  She opened a grocery store five years ago with her husband to sell products like rice, maize, noodles, and snacks.  Demand for their products has increased as their village has grown and they experience a particularly high level of demand from their customers during Nepalese holidays.  Because the important holidays of Dashain and Tihar are soon, Shyam is requesting a loan of $425 to purchase a large stock of grocery items.

loans.use: to buy grocery items

loans.name: Hera Maiju

texts.en:
Hera Maiju M. is a resident of Khokhana, Lalitpur. She lives in a single family with her husband and two sons. Her husband, Mr. Shyam M., is a farmer. He prefers to grow seasonal vegetables on his land. Their older daughter is studying in grade 12 and their younger son is in primary school.

Mrs. M. is a grocery shopkeeper in the village of Khokhana. She opened her grocery store two years ago to improve the living standard of her family. She sells different types of grocery items in her store. Her older son also helps her in her shop.

Now Mrs. M. is asking for Rs 30000.00 loan to invest in her shop to meet the increasing demand of her customers.

loans.use: To buy grocery items

loans.name: Bir Maiya

texts.en:
Mrs. Bir Maiya M. is a grocery shopkeeper in the village of Khokhana. Khokhana is located in Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. Mrs. M. opened her grocery store three years ago to improve the living standard of her family. She sells different verieties of grocery items such as rice, maize, biscuits, noodles, etc. in her shop. In this coming month, the Nepalese celebrate their main festivals, Dashain and Tihar. People buy lots of goods for these festivals, so Mrs. M. is requesting for Rs 15000.00 loan to invest in her shop to meet the increasing demand of her customers.

Mrs. M. lives in a single family with her husband and two children. Her husband, Mr. Dipendra M., works in a private office. Both her daughter and son are studying in Higher Secondary School.

loans.use: To buy grocery items

loans.name: Mina

texts.en:
Mrs. Mina S. lives in Thecho. Thecho is located in Lalitpur district. Thecho is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur. Most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. Mrs. S. has three members including herself in her family. Her husband is a farmer. He grows seasonal vegetables on their land due to lack of modern technology. Her son is studying in primary school.

Mina S. is engaged in duck farming. She has around 10 ducks now. She sells her ducks in the local market. Now the demand for ducks is increasing in the area because people buy ducks to celebrate the Dashain and Tihar festivals, the main festivals of Nepal. So Mrs. S. is requesting for Rs 10000.00 loan to buy more ducks to sell in the local market to meet the increasing demand of the people.

loans.use: To buy ducks

loans.name: Makhaly

texts.fr: M.Makhaly est un chauffeur de taxi ayant capitalise cinq annees d exercice de la profession. Il circule principalement dans l agglomeration dakaroise et parvient a engranger un chiffre d affaires interessant. il compte reparer son taxi tomber en panne et poursuivre son activite
texts.en:
Mr. Makhaly is a taxi driver with 5 years of experience in his job. He operates mainly in the Dakar agglomeration and manages to generate an interesting revenue. He intends to repair his taxi that's broken down, in order to go on with his business.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To repair his taxi

loans.name: Batuli

texts.en: Batuli P., 24 years old, lives in Kritipur, Kathmandu. She lives in a single family with her husband, two daughters and one son, who are studying in primary level. Her husband, Kiran P., is a contractor for building construction. She has no work so she opened small hotel 3 years ago. She seeks Rs 20,000/- to buy food items for her hotel. She earns money to provide a better education for her children and improve the standard of living of her family.

loans.use: To buy food items

loans.name: Shanti

texts.en: Shanti M. is 34 years old and lives in the village of Kritipur, Kathmandu.  She lives with her husband, Jetindra M., and their 14-year-old son, who is currently a high school student.  Shanti works with her husband every day in the grocery store they opened together five years old.  Because demand for their grocery products has increased, Shanti is requesting a loan of $350, which will be used to purchase key grocery items in bulk for resale.  Shanti and her husband hope to use their business' earnings to provide a solid education for their children.

loans.use: To buy grocery items for her shop

loans.name: Serigne

texts.fr:
M. B. est un tailleur tres experimente qui beneficie d une bonne reputation aupres de sa clientele. Il gere un atelier de couture tres cote dans la zone de Guediawaye .
Avec le credit qu il sollicite ; il envisage d acquerir une nouvelle machine pour accroitre sa capacite de production
texts.en:
Mr. B. is a very experienced tailor who enjoys a good reputation with his customers. He manages a tailor's shop very near the Guediawaye area. With this loan that he is requesting, he envisions acquiring a new machine for growing his production capacity.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To acquire a new sewing machine

loans.name: Muna

texts.en: Muna K.C, 39 years old, lives in Kritipur, Kathmandu. She lives in a single family. Her husband, Bhadri Kumar K.C,  is 36 years old. Her daughter and two sons are studying in grade 7, 4 and 1 respectively. She and her husband work together in a vegetable shop which was opened two years ago. Her financial condition is weak so she seeks Rs 20000/- to buy green vegetables. She also wants to earn more to provide a better education for their children.

loans.use: To buy green vegetables

loans.name: Mina

texts.en:
Mina M., 28 years old, lives in Kritipur, Kathmandu. She lives in a single family household with 4 family members: her husband, 30-year-old Shyam M., and two sons who are six years and two years old.

She and her husband work together in their furniture shop. She needs a loan to purchase some materials for their shop like wood, a saw and other items. She seeks Rs 10000/-for her shop in order to earn more and maintain the family .

loans.use: To buy timber and a saw

loans.name: Sun Maiya

texts.en: Sun Maiya L. is 26 years old and lives in Kritipur, Kathmandu, with her husband and their four-year-old son.  Currently her husband works as a construction labourer, while their son studies at the primary level.  Recently, Sun started working as a vegetable farmer and has had success in selling her vegetables in the local village markets.  She is now hoping for a loan of $225, which will be used to purchase fertilizers for her farming operation.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Ram Devi

texts.en: Ram Devi Tamarkar is 42 years old and lives in the Tangal region of Nepal.  She is married and lives with her husband and their two sons.  Rami works alongside her husband in their small hotel, which they opened together ten years ago.  Because the number of customers frequenting her hotel has increased in recent years, Ram is seeking a loan of $425 to purchase materials for improving the quality of the hotel.  She hopes to use the profits to improve the quality of their house and also to provide a better education for their children.

loans.use: To buy materials for a hotel.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To restock her grocery store in order to make it more profitable.

loans.name: Ni Wayan Wiarni

texts.id: Walaupun diusia senja, namun Ibu Wayan Wiarni harus terus berusaha karena suaminya Bapak Ketut Luwer mengalami stroke sejak satu tahun yang lalu. Wiarni memelihara babi dibelakang rumahnya. Dengan modal awal Rp.1.000.000,- Wiarni membeli 1 induk babi, setelah dipelihara selama 6 bulan, induk babi mempunyai anak sebanyak 6 ekor, karena tidak laku terjual akhirnya Wiarni memelihara anak babinya untuk penggemukan. Selain dedak padi dan dedak gandum, Wiarni juga memberi daun-daunanan seperti daun pisang, daun talas, batang pisang, dan juga ampas tahu. Sekarang induk babi sudah melahirkan lagi dan punya anak 9 ekor. Per ekor babi laku terjual seharga Rp.250.000,-. Keuntungan ini dipakai untuk membiayai kebutuhan hidupnya karena suaminya sudah tidak mampu lagi bekerja karena sakit. Harapannya dari pinjaman yang diperoleh dari Dinari Wiarni akan menambah 1 induk babi lagi, dan juga bibit untuk penggemukan, sisanya untuk biaya pakan. Rumahnya dibangun ditanah sendiri, dengan bangunan yang cukup permanen, dan anaknya sudah menikah dan tinggal bersama dengan keluarganya.
texts.en:
Wayan Wiarni has to work to earn money because her husband can no longer work after having a stroke attack last year. Wayan Wiarni is raising piglets for living.

Her initial capital was IDR 1 million (around USD 110) and she spent it for a breeding pig. Six months later the breeding pig had 6 piglets. As she cannot sell the piglets, she has to raise them a bit longer. Now the breeding pig already had more piglets. She is now having 9 piglets. She can sell one piglet for IDR 250 thousand (around USD 28). This money is used to finance her family daily needs.

She is hoping to get loan money from DINARI to be able to buy one more breeding pig and also to buy pig foods.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy breeding pig (Membeli induk babi dan anak babi)

loans.name: Ni Putu Susiyani

texts.id: Putu Susiyani seorang ibu rumah tangga yang punya kegemaran memelihara babi dirumahnya. Dengan modal awal Rp 2.000.000,- Susiyani membeli 2 ekor babi induk, setelah dipelihara selama 6 bulan, 1 ekor induk mempunyai anak 6 ekor , dan induk yang satunya 7 ekor. Anak babi dipelihara selama 2 bulan dan laku terjual Rp. 200.000,- per ekor. Susiyani memberi makan babinya dua kali sehari pada pagi dan sore hari. Selain memberi dedak, Susiyani juga memberikan daun-daunan seperti daun pisang, daun talas, batang pisang. Sebelum diberi makan babinya dimandikan dulu dan kandangnya dibersihkan sampai bersih. Keuntungan yang diperoleh sebanyak Rp.80.00,- perekor, setelah dikurangi biaya pakan. Sekarang Susiyani sudah memelihara babi penggemukan sebanyak 6 ekor dan 2 ekor  induk babi yang masih produktif. Keuntungan yang diperoleh dipakai untuk membantu suaminya yang bekerja sebagai petani untuk memenuhi kebutuhan keluarga dan juga kebutuhan 1 orang anaknya yang masih berumur 4 tahun yang belum bersekolah. Pinjaman yang diperoleh dari Dinari diharapkan dapat menambah beberapa ekor babi lagi dan sisanya untuk biaya pakan ternaknya.
texts.en:
Putu Susiyani is a housewife who also raise pigs at home. Her husband is a farmer. They have a four year old kid. With initial capital of IDR 2 millions (around USD 215) she bought 2 breeding pigs, which after 6 months, they had 13 piglets in total. After 2 months, she can sell the piglets for IDR 200 thousand (around USD 22)/ piglet. She can earn a profit of IDR 80 thousand (around USD 9)/ piglet after deducting all the cost.

She hopes to get loan money to enable her to buy more breeding pigs and to add capital for buy pig foods.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy breeding pigs and pig foods (Membeli anak babi dan pakan)

loans.name: Ni Kadek Sudarmi

texts.id: Walaupun sebagai istri seorang sopir bus, tapi Kadek Sudarmi juga tetap berusaha membantu suaminya untuk memenuhi kebutuhan hidupnya. Sudarmi memelihara babi dengan modal awal Rp. 1.000.000,-. Sudarmi membeli bibit babi untuk dipelihara sebagai penggemukan. Sudarmi memelihara babinya selama 6 bulan, dan laku terjual perekor dari harga Rp. 800.000,- sampai Rp.1.000.000,- . Keuntungan yang diperoleh perekor sebanyak Rp. 80.000,- setelah dikurangi biaya pakan. Selain memberi dedak padi dan dedak gandum, Sudarmi juga memberi makan daun-daunan seperti daun pisang, daun talas dan batang pisang. Sebelum diberi makan babinya dimandikan dahulu sampai bersih dan kandangnya juga dibersihkan. Keuntungan ini dipakai untuk memenuhi kebutuhan hidupnya dan juga untuk membiayai pendidikan anak-anaknya yang masih sekolah. Rumahnya dibangun ditanah sendiri dengan bangunan yang cukup permanen. Harapannya dengan pinjaman yang diperoleh dari Dinari Sudarmi dapat menambah jumlah babinya dan sisanya untuk membeli pakan ternaknya.
texts.en:
Kadek Sudarmi is a housewife. Her husband is a bus driver. She is helping her family by raising pig. Her initial capital IDR 1 million (around USD 107) which she spent for a breeding pig. She can sell all the piglets from this breeding pig for IDR 800 thousand to IDR 1 million where she can earn a profit of IDR 80 thousand (USD 9) per piglet.

She hopes to get the loan money to be able to add the number of piglets.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy pigs and pig foods (Membeli anak babi dan pakan)

loans.name: Ni Ketut Janji

texts.id: Usia yang sudah melebihi setengah abad tidak membuat Ibu Ni Ketut Janji kehilangan semangat hidup. Pengalamannya dalam membesarkan anak-anaknya dengan kehidupan yang sederhana membuatnya selalu optimis dalam setiap keadaan baik senang maupun susah termasuk juga dalam hal membantu suami dalam memenuhi semua kebutuhan keluarga. Usaha yang sudah digelutinya selama bertahun-tahun yang juga sanggup menopang kehidupan keluarganya adalah beternak babi. Ibu Ketut Janji terbiasa memelihara babi penggemukan yang selalu dipeliharanya dalam kandang yang ada dibelakang rumahnya dan jumlah babi yang dipeliharanya biasanya dua sampai tiga ekor saja karena Ibu Ketut Janji tidak memiliki modal yang cukup besar untuk bisa memelihara lebih banyak lagi. Bibit dari babi penggemukan tersebut dibelinya dari kenalannya yang memelihara penginduk sehingga harganyapun tidak terlalu mahal sekitar Rp 270.000 per ekor. Babi tersebut biasanya dipelihara sekitar lima sampai enam bulan dan mampu terjual sekitar Rp 1.000.000 per ekor sehingga Ibu Ketut Janji memperoleh keuntungan sejumlah Rp 400.000 per ekornya. Walaupun keuntungannya tidak terlalu banyak namun hal ini cukup membanggakan bagi Ibu Ketut Janji karena dari hasil usahanya inilah kebutuhan hidup keluarganya bias terpenuhi. Saat ini Ibu Ketut Janiji mengikuti program ternak babi dari Yayasan Dinari dengan jangka waktu pinjaman selama enam bulan dan pembayarannya dilakukan diakhir periode pinjaman yaitu pada bulan ke enam. Dari pinjaman yang diperolehnya dari Dinari Jbu Ketut Janji berharap bias lebih baik lagi dalam menjalakan usahanya.
texts.en:
Ni Ketut Janji is having an optimistic view about life even though she is more than 50 years old. She has been in the business of raising pig for years. With this business she has been able to help her family's economy.

She usually raises 2-3 piglets in one time. She cannot afford to raise more than that. She can buy the piglets from her friend for IDR 270 thousand (around USD 30) per piglets. She then raises them for 5-6 months and re-sell them again for IDR 1 million (around USD 107) per pig. She can earn a profit of IDR 400 thousand (around USD 43) / pig from this.

She is now in the 6 month pig farming program from DINARI. She hopes she can earn more money from this.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy piglets (Membeli anak babi)

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea B. is 47 years old and lives with two of her children in Siem Reap, Cambodia. Since 1988, she and her husband, Khem Tun, 48, have worked together as fishermen and growing rice. On average, they make $3 each day. Two of their children also sometimes help them to fish.

To earn more, Chea has requested a loan of $1000 to breed pigs. This will allow the family to double their daily income. (Khem Tun is pictured outside his home.)

loans.use: To breed pigs

loans.name: Neam

texts.en: Neam S., 29, is married and lives with her husband and four children in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. Since 2005, she has been working as farmer growing rice to earn a profit US$2.5 each day. Her husband, Hoeung Sam, 37, is a miller. He has a grinding machine and is able to make US$3.5 each day. Three of their children are students and the other one is too young to attend school. Neam told a loan officer that on average her family needs to spend around US$60 on food, US$30 on utilities, and US$50 on their children's education. Neam is asking for a loan of US$600 to purchase more rice for her husband to grind and sell. (Hoeung is pictured at his home.)

loans.use: To purchase more rice for her husband to grind and sell.

loans.name: Soeun

texts.en:
Soeun R., 32, is married and lives with two of her children in Siem Reap, Cambodia. Since 1998, she and her husband, Prum Kun, 33, have worked on their rice field to earn a living and are able to make $2.50 each day. Farming is unreliable, because sometimes the crop is damaged by bad weather. The unreliability of farming means they have less money to support the family.

Soeun R. is requesting a loan of $600 to invest with her brother, who sells used phones in the market. She will be able to increase her income through creating a new business with her brother.

loans.use: Sell used phones in the market

loans.name: Chanreung's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanreung R., 28, sells many products from her house, including vegetables, meats, and food ingredients. She has been selling groceries since 2005 and earns approximately US$4.00 per day. Her husband, Mr. Ratha Sok, 27, is a motorcycle taxi driver who earns US$4.00 per day. Ratha also cares for one child in the family's home.

Chanreung lacks the capital to improve her business. She would like to request a loan of US$350 to purchase more grocery inventory to sell.

Chanreung is a leader of small group that has three other members:

  • Mrs. Vuey C., 34, is a farmer. She would like to request a loan of US$250 to buy vegetable seeds to grow.
  • Mrs. Channy B., 28, sells perfume. She would like to request US$350 to purchase more perfume to sell.
  • Mrs. Ry N., 48, sells vegetables in the market. She would like to request a loan of US$350 to purchase more vegetable inventory to sell.
The women all live Chomka Somrong Commune, Battam Bang Province.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery inventory to sell

loans.name: Shamim

texts.en:
Shamim Baji is a wife of M. and lives in a city named Kasur, Pakistan. Kasur city is famous for its sweetmeat and decorative embroidery. She owns a two-room, brick house and has been living in it for the last 25 years. She is the mother of one son who is just eight months old.

Shamim Baji's husband is a milk seller with 10 years experience. He has two buffaloes at his house. Shamim Baji helps her husband in getting milk from the buffaloes. She is applying for a loan to buy another buffalo to expand her husband's milk business.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo to expand milk business.

loans.name: Nen's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Nen V., 58, sells porridge in the primary school, and earns around $2.20 per day. She has six children; three are married, one daughter is a hairdresser, and one son is a restaurant cook. Her husband, Mr. Yun Yen, 63, is a taxi driver with a bicycle that has a trailer. With an increasing number of customers, Nen needs to expand her business. She is requesting a loan of $350 to purchase more raw ingredients and meats to make porridge.

Mrs. Nen is a group leader with two other group members. Mrs. Touch Y., 31, sells vegetables. She requests a loan of $250 to purchase more vegetable to sell. Mrs. Saroeun K., 38, provides a photo-scanning service. She requests a loan of $350 to purchase a second-hand motorcycle to use for business transportation. They live in the Ratanak Commune, Battem Bang Province.

loans.use: Purchase more raw ingredients and meat to make porridge to sell

loans.name: Ean

texts.en:
Mrs. Ean S., 30, is married with three children and works as a rice farmer. She grows rice twice a year, depending on the season. In Cambodia, there are two big seasons: dry season and rainy season. The majority of farmers can grow their crops in both seasons, but sometimes they face a problem with water irrigation in a dry season.

Mrs. Ean S. can earn around $1.50 each day from selling her crops. Her husband can make about $5 per day working at a construction site. To increase her family's income, Mrs. Ean S. requests a loan from Kiva to purchase pigs to breed so that she can earn additional income when she sells those pigs six to seven months later. (Her husband is pictured here because Mrs. Ean S. was not available.)

loans.use: Purchase pigs to breed for addtional income

loans.name: Thouk's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Thouk T., 37, decorates houses for wedding ceremonies. Her business depends on the wedding party. She earns around $3.00 per day, and cares for two children her the family home. Her husband, Mr. Sophara P., 42, is a policeman. Thouk requests a loan of $250 to purchase more decorative materials to use for her business so she can increase her income to meet her family's expenses.

Mrs. Thouk is a group leader, and her group includes two other members. They live in Ratanak Commune, Battembang Province. Mrs. Sreyaun P., 36, has houses for rent. She requests a loan of $300 to make repairs to her rental house to satisfy customers. Mrs. Hort K., 40, makes jars to sell. She requests a loan of $300 to purchase clay for making jars.

loans.use: Purchase more decorative materials for house decorations for wedding parties

loans.name: Nashima

texts.en: Nashima K. is 30 years old and lives in Tangal, Lalitpur with her 34-year-old husband and two sons.  Nashima works with her husband in their watch shop, which they opened together five years ago.  In their shop, Nashima and her husband sell watches and repair timepieces that local people bring to them.  Because her shop would be more efficient and profitable with better tools and a wider variety of products, Nashima is requesting a loan of $150.  She aspires to use the profits to put her two sons through school and thereby better the situation of her family.

loans.use: To buy watches and tools.

loans.name: Sangita

texts.en: Sangita C. is 25 years old and lives in Tangal, Lalitpur, in a joint family household with five close relatives.  Her father works with Sangita in the family's grocery shop, while her mother is a housewife.  The grocery shop is the source of income for her entire family, and therefore Sangita is eager to take out a loan of $350, which will be used to purchase special items such as rice, chocolates, and other goods requested by their customers.  Sangita hopes to use the profits to improve her family's standard of living by sharing it with them.

loans.use: To purchase special grocery items.

loans.name: Amita

texts.en: Amita P., 24, lives in Kirtipur, Kathmandu. She is very energetic. She lives with her husband Prem P. and one-year-old daughter. For two years, she and her husband have grown vegetables. She grows lots of pumpkins, potatoes, corn, and a variety of beans. Now she seeks a loan of Rs.15000 ($250 USD) to buy vegetable seeds and tools for her farming. She takes her vegetables to the local markets every day. She wants to maintain her standard of living of her family.

loans.use: To  buy vegetables seeds and tools for her farming

loans.name: Kanchi

texts.en: Kanchi T. is 30 years old and lives in Bhodhoka, Lalitpur, with her husband and son.  While her son is currently a student in primary school, Kanchi and her husband work in a small hotel which they opened together two years ago.  In the hotel, they serve traditional Newari foods, which are very popular in Bhodhoka because the majority of the people are Newari.  Having paid off her first loan from Kiva, which helped establish her hotel business, Kanchi is requesting another loan of $225, which will be used to purchase meat and vegetables to improve the quality and diversity of food served at her hotel.

loans.use: To purchase more food items.

loans.name: Gita

texts.en: Gita R. is 28 years old and lives in the village of Bholdhoka, Lalitpur, with her mother, husband, and three children.  Gita's husband is a driver for a brick factory, and her eldest daughter and son are in grade five and grade three, respectively.  Gita manages a small grocery store in her village, and already used a loan from Kiva to purchase additional food items, which were helpful in increasing the number of customers who purchase products from her store.  Having paid off her first loan, Gita is now hoping to borrow $225, which she will use to purchase a larger quantity of green vegetables, potatoes, and other food items.  She hopes to use the profits to contribute to her children's education and also to improve the standard of living enjoyed by her family.

loans.use: To buy vegetables

loans.name: Aisha's Allah Karim Group

texts.en:
Aisha, 30, is the divorced mother of two children aged 11 and 2 years old. A clothes seller since 2000, she works daily from 8 a.m. to 3 p.m. and can earn a monthly profit of about $155 from her sales.

Aisha now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes to improve her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses selling clothes, khanga, vegetables, and baby clothes.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to resell.

loans.name: Zainab's Allah Karim Group

texts.en:
Zainab, 49, is married with three children between the ages of 4 and 8. She has operated her own food shop since 1999, working daily from 7 a.m. to 9:30 p.m. and earning a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

Zainab is now requesting a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses operating a general shop, selling clothes, and retailing CD’s.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Chim

texts.en:
Mrs. Chhim V., 43, is married and sells groceries to the people in her area. She has five children aged 16, 14, 12, 9, and an infant. She earns about $5 per day. Her husband makes about $7 per day working as a fisherman.

For another source of income, Mrs. Chhim V. requests a loan to purchase a plot of farmland for her husband to grow rice when he is not fishing.

loans.use: Purchase a plot of farmland to grow rice for additional income

loans.name: Shahodat

texts.en: A. Shahodat is 53 years old. She is married and is the loving mother of five children. Shahodat is a market vendor. She started out eight years ago with only a few products, but her business is currently more stable. Shahodat is selling fruits and vegetables such as: pears, grapes, apples, tomatoes, and cucumbers. Her youngest daughter who is pictured in the photo helps Shahodat with the business. In the market she is known by people because of her attractive prices and friendly nature. All this allows Shahodat’s business to generate a stable and considerable income for her family. Now, her goods are in great demand. For this reason, she is planning to purchase new, fresh fruits and vegetables in order to restock her store, thus expanding her business. For this purpose, she is requesting a loan of $1000, which she will repay in 12 months. She hopes to increase her income in order to pay her children’s university fees. With your help, this will be possible. Shahodat would like to thank everyone for supporting her.

loans.use: Purchasing fruits

loans.name: Khairia

texts.en:
Khairia, 32, is married with four children between the ages of 15 and 6. A clothes seller since 2002, she works daily from 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

Khairia is now requesting a loan to buy more clothes for resale to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale to improve her business.

loans.name: Kunduz

texts.en:
Kunduz A. is 48 years old. She is married with six children. She started her own business 11 years ago because her husband’s salary was not enough for their family expenses. Kunduz is selling confectionery such as candies, cookies, and pastries in the local market.

Kunduz buys her goods from the neighboring city of Dushanbe. She has been working with IMON for more than a year, having a positive credit history. The generated income allows Kunduz to support her large family. She also is dreaming of educating all of her children through higher education.

Today Kunduz is requesting 2000 Somoni (600 USD) for a term of 9 months. She is going to spend the loan purchasing confectionery to expand her range of goods. The income she will make she is planning to spend on purchasing a private store as well as for educating her children. Kunduz thanks all for their support and promises to repay the loan on time.

loans.use: Enlarging her range of goods and with the generated income, purchasing a private store

loans.name: Semeni

texts.en:
Semeni, a clothes seller since 2005, is the married mother of four children between the ages of 12 and 1. She works daily from 9 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Semeni is now requesting a loan to buy more clothes for the improvement of her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for the improvement of her business.

loans.name: Tutigul

texts.en:
Tutigul F. is 43 years old. She is married and has three children. Thirteen years ago, Tutigul began selling clothes in the market, since her income was not enough to cover her children’s expenses being that she is a single mother. That was how she got a taste of the business and learned that she could make sufficient revenue to support her family. Currently, she works in this business full-time, and thanks to her enthusiasm, she has made a name for herself in the market. 

However, her clients request more and more things each day, which is why Tutigul is requesting a loan for 3500 Somoni ($1025 USD), which she will repay in a six months. With this money, Tutigul will be able to purchase more clothing and, therefore, give her business a boost. With your help, Tutigul will be able to help her children prosper so that they may one day go to

loans.use: To buy new clothing

loans.name: Sokina

texts.en: Sokina K. is 41 years old. She is married and has five children. Sokina’s husband is currently working in Russia. It was the only way for him to earn money and support his family.  He could not find a job near home and was without a job for a long time. That is how Sokina ended up as an entrepreneur. Sokina sells children’s clothing in the central market. She offers a large variety of clothing items at a reasonable price. Sokina has been in this trade for 11 years and gained a rich experience in this kind of activity. Today Sokina is requesting a loan of $1000 USD to purchase winter clothing for children. She promises to repay the loan within 12 months. Her long-term plan is to open one more vending facility. Moreover, Sokina is hoping to use the profit to help her daughter get a good education in the University. We believe her enthusiasm, motivation, and desire to improve her living standards will guarantee prompt loan repayment.

loans.use: To buy children's winter clothing

loans.name: Thuwaiba's Allah Karim Group

texts.en:
Thuwaiba, 28 and the married mother of two children aged four and one, has run her own retail shop since 2004. She works daily from 8:30 a.m. to 11 p.m. and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Thuwaiba now hopes for a loan to buy more commodities for the improvement of her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Mashavu, who also has a business dealing with food sales.

loans.use: To buy more commodities for the improvement of her business.

loans.name: Zikusooka Women's Group

texts.en:
Christine N. is chairperson of Zikusooka women's group in Nkokonjeru, Lugazi. She has made a living selling nets to fishermen at two landing sites since 1985, and is well known for her work. Christine says that there are 25 types of nets on the market, but about 5 have been suspended by the Ministry of Trade and Fisheries. She sells the remaining 20 types to her customers, who live as far away as seven miles from her home.

Christine is married and has seven children, but also cares for three relatives and an orphan. She started getting loans seven years ago, and they have changed her life dramatically. She has been able to join with her husband to buy several plots of land for farming, build a small house, and make plans to complete a larger one that can accommodate everyone.

Christine says her business is doing well -- recently the lake was not in a good condition, but thank God it is now in great shape and everyone is happy. Christine dreams of one day opening up a retail shop that will sell cold drinks, soaps and cereals so that she can work in one place as she grows older and her legs become more painful. She is thankful for her husband's help in raising their children and helping them become educated. She will use her potion of the loan to buy more fishing nets to sell.

loans.use: To buy more nets to sell to local fisherman.

loans.name: Halima's Mwanzo Mgumu Group

texts.en:
Halima, 30 years old, is married with one child aged 4 years old. She has been a bed sheet and khanga (African garment) seller since 2005, working daily from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. at her business and earning a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

Halima now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for resale to improve her business. She will share this loan with Mwema, her subgroup member, who also has a clothing sales business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale to improve her business.

loans.name: Ruzigul

texts.en: Ruzigul N. is 54 years old. She is married and has four adult children. Despite her ripe old age, her energy shines in her activities. She started her own business 10 years ago because she didn’t have a job at that time. She wanted to make sure that her family had enough money. Ruzigul is a market vendor. She sells fruits and vegetables in a market that is known among people because of the attractive prices. This allows Ruzigul’s business to generate a stable income for her family. Today she is planning to purchase more fresh fruits and vegetables to fulfill the needs of a growing number of customers. For this purpose, she requests a loan of 2400 Somoni ($725 USD) for the term of 12 months. The well-being of this family is in your hands. Help them by contributing to the growth of Ruzigul’s business, and they will sincerely thank you.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank has eight members and is located in Preak Ta Ten Village in Kandal Province. Mrs. Li L., the Village Bank president, was selected by the members to be the group leader. She is a farmer who cultivates both vegetables and rice. Since her vegetable field now is infertile, Mrs. Li L. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer to improve her field. With the rest of the loan, she plans to buy more seeds to grow more vegetables.

Her husband, Mr. Phuong Vantha, is a fisherman, who gathers very few fish. Mrs. Li L. is 34 years old, and the mother of three children: two attend the local school, and the youngest one is 5 years old, and too young to work or study.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer to improve the field to produce more crops

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha, 55, is married with four children between the ages of 24 and 7 years old. She has been a clothing and juice seller since 2005, working daily from 10:30 a.m. to 7 p.m. and earning a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Asha is now requesting a loan to increase her current stock for the improvement of her business.

loans.use: To increase her current stock for the improvement of her business.

loans.name: Fatma

texts.en:
Fatma, a 49-year-old divorced mother of one child aged three, has been a food seller since 1994. She works daily from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

Fatma is now requesting a loan to buy more food items such as rice, wheat flour and beans for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Mrs. Chheang Sothy Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twenty members in Slab Ta Aon Village in Kandal Province formed a village bank loan, and they plan to use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Chheang S., the village bank president, is a garment worker who makes $55 per month. She is 28 years old and the mother of two children, aged 5 and 2. Her monthly income is a small amount to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Sreng Chamroeun, is a construction worker who earns $4 per day, which goes toward paying the family's expenses.

Mr. Sreng Chamroeun's business now faces a small problem because he does not have enough construction materials to build the houses for his customers. Mrs. Chheang S. requests a loan to buy construction materials for her husband's business.

loans.use: Buy construction equipment for home construction business

loans.name: Mwanakhamis

texts.en:
Mwanakhamis is a widow with three children aged between 39 and 26 years old. She has been a charcoal and coconuts seller since 1999. Every day she works from 7.30am to 3.30pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

Mwanakhamis is now looking for a loan to buy more charcoal and coconuts in order to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and coconuts  for re-sale.

loans.name: Rahma

texts.en:
Rahma is 36 years old. She is married with one child aged 15. She has run her own shop, a general store, since 2005, working from 8am to 8pm at her business. She can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Rahma is now looking for a loan to buy more commodities to increase her present stock in order to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities to increase her present stock.

loans.name: Rahma

texts.en:
Rahma is 36 years old. She is married with one child aged 15. She has run her own shop, a general store, since 2005, working from 8am to 8pm at her business. She can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Rahma is now looking for a loan to buy more commodities to increase her present stock in order to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities to increase her present stock to improve her business.

loans.name: Stefani Group

texts.en:
"Stefani" group is composed of women who plan to work for the improvement of their families' livelihoods. This loan will be the third with A. Majmoua for these women.

Fatmeh is 29 years old, married, and lives in the suburbs of Beirut. Fatmeh runs a cotton clothing shop in her neighborhood. Fatmeh has requested a loan of $400 to help her purchase additionA. inventory to sell in order to expand her business. Fatmeh is pictured here.

Zahra, not pictured, is 29 years old, married with 2 children, and lives in the suburbs of Beirut. Zahra is a beautician in her neighborhood and has benefited much from loans she has received in the past. This new loan will continue to help her business be successful and provide much needed income for her family. Zahra has also requested $400 to expand her business.

loans.use: To help the women of Stefani group develop their small businesses

loans.name: Stefani Group

texts.en:
"Stefani" group is composed of women who plan to work for the improvement of their families' livelihoods. This loan will be the third with A. Majmoua for these women.

Fatmeh is 29 years old, married, and lives in the suburbs of Beirut. Fatmeh runs a cotton clothing shop in her neighborhood. Fatmeh has requested a loan of $400 to help her purchase additionA. inventory to sell in order to expand her business. Fatmeh is pictured here.

Zahra is 29 years old, married with 2 children, and lives in the suburbs of Beirut. Zahra is a beautician in her neighborhood and has benefited much from loans she has received in the past. Zahra is pictured here beautifying one of her loyA. clients. This new loan will continue to help her business be successful and provide much needed income for her family. Zahra has also requested $400 to expand her business.

loans.use: To help the women of Stefani group develop their small businesses

loans.name: Hadia's Imani Yetu Group

texts.en:
Hadia is 40 years old. She is divorced with 7 children aged between 22 and 1 year old. She has been a clothes and bread seller since 2000. Every day, she works from 7am to 9:30pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Hadia is now seeking a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members MwaJ. and Rehema, who have businesses selling food and soap and dressmaking.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to bolster her business

loans.name: Mrs. Shing Chandavy Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank, located in Slab Ta Aon Village in Kandal Province, consists of 15 people who plan to use their share of the loan for a variety of purposes. Mrs. Shing C., a 27-year-old widow with a child yet too young to attend school, is the Village Bank President. As the owner of a successful grocery store in the local market, she is requesting a loan to buy more grocery products to meet customer demand. Shing hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this loan.

Mrs. Set Saran is represented in the picture by her husband..

loans.use: To buy more grocery products to meet customer demand.

loans.name: Thi Loan's Group

texts.vi:
chị N. thị Loan năm nay 47 tuổi, Ms 01020011 đã tham gia vay vốn của chương trình qua hai chu kỳ và hoàn trả rất tốt. Chu kỳ này chị đăng ký vay mức 4.704.000 VND để kinh doanh thịt lợn. Hiện tại chị đang sống cùng chồng và 1 con, con chị đang đi học lớp 10. Hàng ngày chồng chị làm kinh doanh, chị đi chợ nên mức thu nhập của gia đình chị khá ổn định từ 150.000 VND đến 180.000 VND / ngày. chị rất thích tham gia hình thức vay trả này vì nó giúp vợ chồng chị tích kiệm tiền, đồng thời có kế hoạch cho tương lai của con cái. Nhóm chị có các thành viên sau :

  • chị N. thị Dân Ms 01020012 vay mức 4.256.000 VND để sản xuất đồ gỗ .
  • chị Nguyễn thị Hà Ms 01020013 vay mức 4.256.000 VND để chăn nuôi lợn và mua lợn giống
  • chị N. thị Hoa Ms 01020014 vay mức 4.256.000 VND để chăn nuôi lợn.
  • anh N. đình Tính Ms 01020015 vay mức 4.256.000 VND để mua gỗ làm bàn ghế bán
texts.en:
Mrs N. thị Loan is 47 years old. She has already paid back 2 loans. This time she is seeking 4.704.000 VND. She is married and has 1 child who is in 10th grade. Her husband sells pork and she trades basic goods. Her family income is stable, 150.000 - 180.000 VND a day. She likes SEDA program very much because it enables her to save and plan a better future for her child. Other members in her group are:
  • Mrs N. thị Dân who is seeking 4.256.000 VND to manufacture wooden furniture.
  • MrsNguyễn thị Hà who is seeking 4.256.000 VND to buy breeding pigs
  • Mrs N. thị Hoa who is seeking 4.256.000 VND. She raises pigs.
  • Mr N. đình Tính who is seeking 4.256.000 VND to buy wood to manufacture

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy/sell pork

loans.name: Bilal

texts.en:
Bilal is 24 years old and single. He lives in the suburbs of Beirut where he owns a motorcyle maintenance business. His friends describe him as a very hard-working and determined man.

Bilal wants to get married and has requested a loan of US$ 1,000 which will help with the costs of the wedding. Bilal is hoping to have some money left over to purchase new parts for his business as well. This is the first time that Bilal will be working with Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To help cover the costs of Bilal's upcoming wedding and to purchase a new inventory of parts for his motorcycle repair business

loans.name: Saada's Mpaji Ni Mungu Group

texts.en:
Saada is 47 years old. She is divorced with two children aged 18 and 11. She has been a clothes seller since 2005. Every day, she works from 7.30am to 4pm, earning a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Saada now seeks a loan to buy more clothes for re-sale. She will share this loan with her sub-group members, Mosi and Zainab, who have businesses dealing with clothes sales and perfumes sales.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for re-sale.

loans.name: Keti

texts.en:
Keti is 48 years old. She is married with 3 children, ages between 17 and 6 years old. She has been a shoe and clothing seller since 2000. Every day, she works from 7:30 am to 4:30 pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Keti is now requesting a loan to buy more shoes and clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have  businesses dealing with

loans.use: To buy more shoes and clothes for her business.

loans.name: Mohammad Shakar

texts.en:
Mohammad Shakar is 23 years old and married with one son. He was for a long time in Iran. Two years ago he left Iran and came back to Afghanistan. He has a cosmetics shop. He was involved in this business in Iran and then started one up in Kabul; he has some good numbers of customers but he needs to buy more cosmetics for re-sale.

Mohammad Shakar has requested an individual loan of 50,000 Afghani with a term of 18 months to complete his stock and also buy new designs of clothes for males and females to attract more customers and make a good monthly income for his family to help his family and make a better future for himself.

He would like to thank Kiva lenders around the world. He wants to become strong and popular to have anther shop in the future. He would love to continue his business with AFSG and Kiva.

loans.use: To complete his stock and buy new designs of clothes for re-sale

loans.name: Cissy Nakanga's Group

texts.en:
Cissy, 35, is the leader of a four-person group. She is married and has three children between the ages of 4 and 14. All of her children go to school. She resides in and owns a five-room house where she is staying with five people. There is electricity but no piped water at her home. Cissy is looking after three orphans of her late brother.

The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. For 10 years, Cissy has run a restaurant and bar in Bwaise one of the city suburbs. She sells to an average of 20 people a day, and works seven days a week. She rides a bicycle between home and work. Cissy's monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

Cissy's main challenges are seasonality and con men. She bought a money detector in order to detect fake money. Cissy has been with MCDT for many years and this is her sixteenth loan with the same group of women. She wants to use this loan to increase stock in her business and is aspiring to open another restaurant in Kawempe.

loans.use: To boost her business

loans.name: Tabia

texts.en:
Tabia is 26 years old. She is married with a child aged six years. She has been a clothes seller since 2007. Every day, she works from 7am to 9pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Tabia is now looking for a loan to buy more clothes to increase her inventory and improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to improve her business.

loans.name: Menghor's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. MengH. H., 41, sells fish in the Khpop market. Her husband, Mr. Yung Choum, 48, sells fish by transporting it to customers' home, and earns US$3.00 per day. They live with their nine children. MengH. would like to request a loan of US$350 to purchase more fish to sell. MengH. is the group leader of three members as following:
Mrs. Hean S., 54, a house wife. She would like to request a loan of US$350 to purchase a cart for her children to transport groups of tourists across the Cambodia and Thailand border; Mrs. Pov R., 59, sells fritters. She would like to request a loan of US$350 to add more business capital. The loan will increase her incomes to support her family's living payment adequately; Mrs. Muy C., 53, requests a loan of US$350 to stock more vegetable to sell. They live in Prek Loung Commune, Siem Reap Province.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Chhouk

texts.en: Chhouk S. is 54 years old and lives with one of her children in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 1995, she has been selling shoes in the market to earn a living and is able to make US$5 in profit each day. Previously, she and her husband, Chhu Peng, 55, sold handbags and other stuff, but they have now changed to selling shoes. They sell many kinds of shoes, both female and male. Chhouk would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to add to her shoe inventory. Chhouk told a loan officer that on average she spends US$60 on food, and US$15 on utilities. (Chhu Peng is pictured because his wife was not available.)

loans.use: To add to her shoe inventory

loans.name: Choo

texts.en: Mrs. Choo C., 42, is married and has two children. She works selling various kinds of grocery products and runs a small pharmacy selling different kinds of medicines. She can earn about $10/day of income. Her husband is a Tuk-Tuk (a motorcycle with an attached passenger cart) driver transporting people to different locations in his town, making about $5/day of profit. For the entire family, every day she spends around $2.50 on food, $0.30 on utilities, and $1 on her children's tuition. Mrs. Choo C. has gratefully asked for a loan to expand her business by purchasing more products and medicine to meet her growing customer demand.

loans.use: To purchase more products and medicine

loans.name: Mohammad Saliam

texts.en:
M. Saliam is 20 years old and lives in a household of 5 members. He is a carpet maker and he has looms inside his house. He is new to his business. He lost his father during the war 5 years ago so now he supports his family. He works together with his whole family making carpets and they send carpets to the bazaar for sale.

Now he needs a loan. Therefore he has requested an individual loan to buy a new loom to continue his business with more success in the future.

He is happy with all members of his family. The whole family wants to thank lenders around the world who make this opportunity possible in this poor country. Saliam and all members of his family want to continue their partnership with AFSG and Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a new loom for making carpets as a home industry

loans.name: Zena

texts.en:
Zena is 30 years old, married with four children aged between 11 and 2 years. She has been a bricks seller since 2002. She works every day from 6.30am to 6.30pm at her business.

Zena is now looking for a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Marlene

texts.en: Marlene is 46 years old and lives in Beirut where she works as secretary in a doctor's clinic. Recently, Marlene was forced to move because her home was too far from her office. She has requested a US$ 700 loan to perform maintenance on her new apartment that she has rented near the clinic. This will be Marlene's second loan with Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To help with the costs of maintenance on Marlene's new apartment

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Nguyen Thi M. is 46 years old. Her husband is a pensioner. They have 2 children; one is grown-up and has a stable job. In 1999, she joined TYM Fund and borrowed VND 1 million to raise pigs. For the following loan cycles, she accessed loans to brew rice wine for sale. For the next loan cycles, she is applying for VND 15 million to buy rice and reserve it for this business. With an income of VND 5 million/month, she finds it easy to repay the loan.

loans.use: buying rice to brew rice wine

loans.name: Amina's Sisi Kwa Sisi Group

texts.en:
Amina is 32 years old and married with 5 children between 14 and 1 year old. She has been a snacks and clothes seller since 1999. Every day, she works from 6.30AM to 6.30PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Amina is now looking for a loan to improve her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses dealing with a salon, soap sales and snacks sales.

loans.use: To improve her business.

loans.name: Cao Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Cao Thi T. is 48 years old. Her husband is a pensioner. She joined TYM Fund in 1998 and borrowed VND 500,000 to raise pigs. Up to this time, her family's pig raising business has been expanding. That is why she wants to borrow VND 15 million to fix her pig-pen and buy bran in order to raise more pigs.

loans.use: Pig raising

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Nguyen Thi L. is 40 years old. In 1999, she joined TYM Fund and borrowed her first loan worth VND 1 million to raise ducks. Her business is now in its 10th year and she has expanded following the farm model. At present , her family has a milling machine and it helps increase their total income to VND 4 million/month. For the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow VND 10 million to buy unhusked rice, husk it and sell the rice to local people.

loans.use: buy unhusked rice to husk and sell

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Mrs. Nguyen Thi V. is 37 years old and has been a TYM member since 2002. She borrowed the first loan worth VND 1 million to raise pigs. Up to now as they become more experienced in animal raising, she also raises buffalos to generate more income for the family. What is more, she buys and sells wholesale lemon. Her businesses are going on well and bring about VND 3 million/month. Besides, her husband is a builder and also earns money for the family. For the next cycle, she applies for VND 12 million to fix breeding facilities and buy one more buffalo to raise.

loans.use: Raising

loans.name: Marieta's Tawakal Group

texts.en:
Marieta, 35, is married with two children ages 9 and 2. She has been a milk seller since 2007. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Marieta is now looking for a loan to buy more milk in order to improve her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Fatma, who sells porridge and snacks.

loans.use: To buy more milk for her business.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Nguyen Thi L. joined TYM Fund in 2002. For the first loan cycle, she applied for VND 1 million to raise pigs. At present, besides income from pig raising, she earns VND 2.5 million from broom sales and the salary of her husband, who is a builder. Hence, her family's economy is very stable. For the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow VND 9 million to invest in broom selling and buy more cows to raise.

loans.use: selling brooms and raising cows

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Nguyen Thi H., aged 37, joined TYM Fund in 2002. First she borrowed VND 1 million to invest in pig raising. For the following loans, as she could access bigger loans, she bravely invested her loans in cow raising. Besides, she sells lemon to generate more income for her family. With VND 3 million/month from her businesses and income of her husband, a builder, her family's economy develops ceaselessly. For the next loan cycle, she is applying for VND 15 million to upgrade her breeding facilities and raise more pigs.

loans.use: to upgrade breeding facilities and raise more pigs

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Nguyen Thi H., aged 41, lives with her husband and 3 children in Hung Nguyen district, Nghe An province. Mrs. H. has been a member of TYM Fund since 2006. At present, her family's main business is breeding and selling dog meat. With an income of VND 3.5 million/month, she has been repaying very well. For the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow VND 9 million to invest in this business.

loans.use: Business development

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Tran Thi H. is 31 years old. She joined TYM Fund in 2006. First she borrowed VND 3 million to sell vegetables and fruits. This is now her family's main source of income. For the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow VND 9 million to buy a cow and raise it. With an income of VND 2 million from her existing business, she believes that she can repay the loan in a timely fashion.

loans.use: buying a cow to raise

loans.name: Sikuzani

texts.en:
Sikuzani is 29 years old. She is married with 3 children, ages 8, 6, and 2. She is a clothing and cake seller. Every day she works from 7:00 AM to 3:00 PM at her business.

Sikuzani is now requesting a loan to improve her business by increasing her current stock.

loans.use: To improve her business by increasing her current stock

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.en:
Mrs. Pham Thi T. is a 49-year-old widow. Her husband unluckily passed away a long time ago. So at present she lives with her two children in Hung Nguyen district, Nghe An province. In 2006 she joined TYM Fund.

Today her family's main business is fruit selling. Besides, she has additional income from animal raising. With an income of VND 2 million/month, she has no difficulty in repaying her loans. For the next loan cycle, she is applying for VND 9 million to invest in fruit selling and broom selling.

loans.use: to sell fruit and brooms

loans.name: Sabahi

texts.en:
