She got married very young to Alipio L. with whom she had one son. She was widowed and re-married; with her second spouse, she had 6 children and currently one daughter and one son are still her dependents. Nelva Jesus sells groceries and food; she started with very little capital but now her business has grown and she operates it out of her own home. Her first loan from the Manuela Ramos organization was for $125 and she repaid it in 4 months; she invested it in meat, groceries, and beer. She has been a member of the village bank for 9 years. With this $125 loan which she will repay in 4 payments, she will purchase groceries to supply her business. She dreams of having a beautiful home in the city of Trujillo and living there with her children. Currently, she only belongs to the village bank in Mache.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of groceries

loans.name: Rosa Teonila

texts.es:
La señora Rosa Teonila V. D. R. tiene 74 años  y vive en la plaza D. armas D. Mache, en la calle San Martín 113 en el distrito D. Mache  en la provincia D. Otuzco en el departamento D. La Libertad Perú.
Curso hasta el primer año D. primaria porque según nos manifiesta en su tiempo los padres decían que las mujeres no deben aprender a leer y a escribir porque les iba a servir para escribir cartas D. amor a los hombres y era mejor que tal sabiduría no la aprendieran.
Tiene negocios múltiples porque debe trabajar D. acuerdo a la época, se queda en su bodega en época D. lluvia y sale a fabricar teja en época D. verano, en el que se venD. muy bien el producto.
Recuerda con alegría cuando recibió el primer préstamo que le brindo Manuela Ramos  y fue D. 300 soles, compró material para ampliar su negocio, lo devolvió en cuatro meses, “Manuela confió en mí porque yo no era objeto D. crédito para otros bancos”, lo manifiesta con una amplia sonrisa.
Con este préstamo D. S/. 2000 soles que utilizará en ampliar su negocio D. la bodega porque ya se acerca la época D. frio y tendrá que limitarse a vender en ella.  Este préstamo será devuelto en 4 cuotas.
Su gran sueño es que al llegar a mayor edad su bodega se convierta en una gran tienda donD. ella pueda sentarse a vender.
Rosa pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres D. Mache y también al Comedor Popular Corazón D. María.
texts.en:
Mrs. Rosa Teonila V. D. R. is 74 years old and lives in town square in Mache, on San Martin St. #113, Mache district, Otuzco Province, La Libertad Department, Peru. She was able to attend school up to the first year of primaty school because as she tells us during her time "the parents will say that women should not learned how to read and write because it will allow them to write love letters to men and it was better that they didn't acquire that knowledge".

She has multiple businesses because she works them according to the season, during the rainy season, she stays at her small grcoery store and in summer time she goes to manufacture tiles which sell very well. She remembers with happiness when she received her first loan through Manuela Ramos. It was a 300 soles(Peruvian currency) loan. Rosa bought materials to expand her business and she paid it back in four months. "Manuela trusted me because I was not able to get credit through other banks, she said with a big smile.

With this 2000 soles (Peruvian currency) loan, Rosa will continue to expand her grocery store because the cold season is approaching and she will have to limit herself to sell at the shop. This loan will be paid back in 4 installments. Her big dream is that when she becomes older, her shop will turn into a big store that she can sit down a be able to continue selling.

Rosa belongs to the Women of Mache Comunal Bank and also to the Heart of Mary Local Dining Room


Translated from Spanish by Maria Ramirez-Gregg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying diverse products (groceries)

loans.name: Santos Rosa

texts.es:
La señora Santos Rosa B. L., tiene treintainueve años, vive en la calle San Martín 219 en el distrito de Mache en la provincia de Otuzco en el departamento de La Libertad Perú.
Estudió primaria completa y no siguió estudiando, porque no le gustaba estudiar, manifiesta, le gustaba más el negocio.
Se casó a los diecisiete años con Juber Aredo con el que tuvo una hija mujer y un hijo varón, los que son educados solamente por ella ya que se separó de su pareja.
Empezó su negocio con la venta de quesillo, con ayuda del primer préstamo de Manuela Ramos que fue de 300 soles compró abarrotes con lo que empezó a surtir una bodega. El préstamo lo devolvió en cuatro meses.
Con este préstamo de S/. 2000 soles, el cual cancelará en 4 meses, comprará arroz, azúcar y aceite para continuar surtiendo su tienda.
Rosa es una mujer muy valiente y emprendedora que lucha sola por la vida, enfrentando a una sociedad que no comprende el hecho de ser una madre que lucha sola para educar a dos hijos.
Pertenece al Banco Comunal Progresistas y se desempeña como secretaria.
Sueña con ir de paseo turístico a Chile.
texts.en:
Mrs. Santos Rosa B. L. is 39 years old, lives at 219 San Martín Street in the Mache district in the province of Otuzco in the department of La Libertad, Perú. She completed primary school and did not continue studying because she did not like it. She said she liked business better. When she was seventeen years old she married Juber Aredo with whom she had a daughter and a son. She has raised them alone as she is separated from her husband. She started her business selling cheese and with the help of the first loan from Manuela Ramos which was for 300 soles she bought groceries with which she started to supply a small store. She paid back this loan in four months. With this loan of S/. 2000 soles, which she will pay in 4 months, she will buy rice, sugar and oil to continue supplying her store. Rosa is a very brave and entrepreneurial woman who struggles through life alone, confronting a society that does not understand how it is to be a single mother raising two children. She belongs to the Progresistas Communal Bank and serves as the secretary. She dreams of going on a trip to Chile.

Translated from Spanish by Aimee Sostowski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy varied products (groceries)

loans.name: Santos Victoria

texts.es:
La señora Santos Victoria L. E. tiene 50 años vive en la calle Ricardo Palma sin número del distrito de Mache en la provincia de Otuzco en el departamento de La Libertad Perú.
Victoria estudió por correspondencia Enfermería técnica, es Promotora de Salud en su comunidad.
Se casó a los 28 años con el señor Odilón Vega y tiene seis hijos, de los cuales dependen de ella dos hijas, los otros cuatro viven independientemente.
Santos Victoria se dedica a la compra venta de artículos de primera necesidad, quesillo y animales menores, ella trabaja en su casa.
El primer préstamo obtenido de Manuela Ramos fue de 300 soles que devolvió en cuatro meses, gracias al cual amplió su negocio.
Con este crédito de S/ 2,500 soles, para devolverlos en cuatro meses, comprará dos ovejas, un cerdo, trigo, cebada y papa seca.
Su sueño más grande es tener un gran negocio en Trujillo porque quiere vivir cerca de sus hijos que viven allí.
Victoria es presidenta de promotores de salud de su zona y presidenta de su Banco Comunal Mujeres de Mache.
texts.en:
Mrs. Santos Victoria L. E. is 50 years old and lives on Ricardo Palma Street in Mache, Otuzco in the state of La Libertad, Peru. She studied technical nursing and works as a health promoter in her community. She got married at the age of 28 to Odilon Vega and she has six children; two of whom are still dependent and the other four live independently. Santos Victoria works selling necessities, cheese, and small animals out of her home. The first loan she received from the Manuela Ramos organization was for $125 and she repaid it in 4 months; thanks to the loan, she was able to grow her business. With this loan of $850 which she will repay in 4 months, she will purchase two sheep, one pig, wheat, barley, and dried potato. Her dream is to have a large business in the city of Trujillo because she would like to live close to her children who live there. She is the president of the health promoters in her neighborhood and president of the Women of Mache village bank.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of animals (sheep, pigs).  Purchase of grains (wheat, barley) and dried potatoes

loans.name: Juntas Progresaremos Group

texts.es:
El distrito peruano D. Yauli es uno D. los 19 distritos D. L. Provincia D. Huancavelica, en el Departamento D. Huancavelica, en Perú. L. creación del pueblo D. Yauli, obedece sobre todo a L. construcción del ferrocarril Huancayo – Huancavelica. Yauli está localizada a 3.385 msnm. El Bancomunal Juntas Progresaremos tiene 12 socias que solicitan un préstamo D. 6,700 nuevos soles para implementar sus negocios.

Leonarda O., se dedica a L. venta D. papa, queso, también realiza manualidades D. tejido como guantes, medias y chalinas. Leonarda es viuda y tiene 4 hijos a su cargo, elL. solicita un préstamo D. 1000 nuevos soles que invertirá en L. compra D. lana D. calidad, para incrementar su negocio y así aumentar sus ventas. Su sueño es tener su casa propia y tener su pequeña empresa textil.

Maximiliana C., es casada y tiene 6 hijos. Su negocio es L. venta D. abarrotes, gaseosas, ropa, zapatos. Maximiliana solicita un préstamo D. 300 soles para invertir en su negocio, Maximiliana desea que sus hijos tengan estudios y no sean analfabetos como elL..

Benigna S., es casada y tiene 5 hijos todos en edad escolar. Benigna realiza toda clase D. tejidos que venD. después, elL. desea un préstamo D. 1000 soles para invertir en una pequeña tiendecita que quiere poner en su casa.
texts.en:
The Peruvian district of Yauli is one of 19 districts in Huancavelica Province, in the department of the same name. The village of Yauli was created because of the nearby construction of the Huancayo Railroad, in Huancavelica. Yauli sits at 3,385 meters above sea level. The Juntas Progresaremos (Together We Will Progress) Communal Bank is maD. up of 12 women who are requesting a loan of 6,700 nuevo soles to implement their respective businesses.

Leonarda O. sells potatoes and cheese and also hand-knits gloves, socks and ties. Leonarda is a widow and the mother of four children. She is requesting a loan of 1000 nuevos soles to buy high-quality wool and to expand her business so that she can sell more. She dreams of owning her own home and of starting a small textile company.

Maximiliana C. is married and has six children. She sells dry goods, soda, clothing and shoes. She is requesting a loan of 300 soles to invest in her business. Maximiliana wants her children to go to school so that they learn to read, something she never learned to do.

Benigna S. is married with five school-age children. Benigna knits all sorts of things to sell. She is requesting a loan of 1000 soles to open a small store in her house.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy wool and merchandise to sell, open a store

loans.name: Alicia Agustina

texts.es:
La señora Alicia Agustina U. A. tiene cuarenta y ocho años y vive en el caserío Buenos Aires del distrito de Mache, provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La  Libertad  Perú.
Alicia Agustina estudió primaria completa pero no contó con apoyo económico para poder continuar.
Tiene su pareja desde los treintaicuatro años y de ese compromiso tiene dos hijas y dos hijos los aun son estudiantes.
Tiene una bodega y también compra ovejas y cerdos, los que los vende en carne, es una mujer muy dinámica por lo que no realiza un solo tipo de negocio, también fabrica pan en horno de leña  y es el mejor de la zona.
Manuela Ramos le prestó 300 soles por primera ves con los que amplió su negocio, devolvió el préstamo en cuatro meses y fue muy cumplida.
Con este préstamo de S/ 2,000 soles, el cual será  pagado en 4 cuotas, comprará animales para venderlos al por menor (carne) y artículos para su bodega. 
Ella manifiesta estar muy agradecida del Movimiento Manuela Ramos porque le enseño a disciplinar su vida y administrar bien su negocio.
Alicia Agustina pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres de Mache.
Sueña con tener una gran bodega con la que pueda abastecer a todo su caserío y aledaños.
texts.en:
Ms. Alicia Agustina U. A. is a 48-year-old woman who lives in the Buenos Aires residential development in the Mache district, in the Otuzco province, in La Libertad Perú. Alicia Agustina finished elementary school but was unable to continue her studies due to a lack of financial support. She and her 34-year-old partner have two daughters and two sons, who are all in school. She owns a general store and also buys sheep and pigs, which she sells as meat. She is a very dynamic woman which is why she does not only dedicate herself to one type of business. She also makes bread using a wood-burning oven, and she is the best in the zone. Manuela Ramos lent her 300 PEN the first time, with which she expanded her business. She repaid the loan in 4 months and was very punctual. With this loan of 2,000 PEN, which will be rapaid in 4 installments, she will purchase goods for her general store and livestock to be sold as retail meat. She says that she is very appreciative of the Manuela Ramos movement because it has helped her to lead a disciplined life and administer her business well. Alicia Agustina is a member of the Mujeres de Mache (Women of Mache) microfinance institute. She dreams of having a large general store that will meet the needs of not only her residential development, but also the ones in surrounding areas.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase livestock for meat and assorted goods for general store

loans.name: Virgen De La Candelaria Group

texts.es:
L. comunidad D. Sachabamba, esta ubicado aproximadamente a una hora D. L. comunidad D. Condorccocha, pertenece al distrito D. Chiara y provincia D. Huamanga, esta Comunidad cuenta con aproximadamente con 80 familias que viven en L. comunidad, los comuneros se dedican a L. siembra D. cereales como trigo, cebada, maíz, arveja y tubérculos como papa, mashua, olluco, etc. L. comunidad tiene su propia feria ubicado en L. plaza principal.

Julia H. N., compra todo tipo D. cereales y tuberculos, los lleva a Ayacucho para comercializar. Julia desea mejorar su trabajo para que sus hijos puedan estudiar y sean profesionales. Julia desea ahorrar para invertir en L. educación D. sus hijos y tener su propio negocio.

Alicia Palomino, tiene una tienda D. abarrotes, también en época escolar venD. zapatos y útiles. A Alicia le gustaría mejorar su tiendita D. abarrotes, para hacer estudiar a sus hijos, elL. desea que tengan mejores oportunidades.

Irma C. A., compra y venD. animales menores, también venD. queso. Le gustaría tener un carro para poder hacer mejor su negocio, para ello ahorrara mucho. DesD. que esta en Finca elL. dice que ha aprendido a respetarse a si misma y ahora sabe que también tiene las mismas facultades que los varones, hace bien su negocio y tiene dinero mas que su esposo, Irma aporta mas a L. casa en los gastos. Ha aprendido a capitalizarse y trabajar en equipo con las socias, ellas le dan sus productos, las compra y lleva a Ayacucho.
texts.en:
The community Sachabamba is located approximately one hour from the community Condorccocha. It is part of the District of Chiara and the Province of Huamanga. This community has about 80 families that live there. These people are dedicated to the cultivation of cereal grains like wheat, barley, corn, peas, and tubers like potatoes, olluco and mashua (local perennial tubers), etc. This community has its own market located in the central square. Julia H. N. buys all sorts of cereals and tubers, and she takes them to Ayacucho in order to sell them. Julia would like to improve her work so that her children would be able to study and become professionals. Julia would like to save in order to invest in the education of her children and to have her own business. Alicia Palomino has a snack store. When she was a student, she used to sell shoes and household goods. Alicia would like to enlarge her little snack store, in order that her children could study. She wants them to have better opportunities. Irma C. A. buys and sells small animals. She also sells cheese. She would like to have a car in order to improve her business, and for this she would save a great deal. Over time here on the farm, she says that she has learned to respect herself, and now she knows that she also has the same abilities as the men. Her business is going well and she has more money than her husband. Irma does a lot for the household expenses. She has learned to build capitol and work with tools with the women’s groups, they give her their products, and she buys them and takes them to Ayacucho.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Loans for 15 Group Members

loans.name: Costa Rica Group

texts.es:
L. comunidad D. San José D. Sucre esta ubicado 30 minutos del distrito D. Cangallo, esta comunidad mayormente se dedican a L. producción D. frutales y cultivo D. alfalfa, pero es poco L. producción D. cereales y L. mayoría D. L. gente se dedica al negocio.

Irma Agüero, venD. frutas en Huancapi y Cangallo, tambien cria cuyes y venD. cereales. A Irma le gustaria tener su propia movilidad para mejorar sus plantaciones D. frutales. Irma a aprendido a ahorrar en las reuniones D. su bancomunal.

Olga Gutiérrez, tiene una pequeña tienda D. abrrotes, tambien da pension (alimentos) a trabajadores D. L. carretera y profesores. Con su prestamo quiere mejorar su negocio, tambien desea ahorrar para los estudios D. sus hijos.

Marcelina P., venD. chicha D. siete semillas, tambien venD. abarrotes en una tiendecita que tiene. Marcelina tiene muchos sueños como el salir adelante junto a sus hijos, elL. nos dice: “cuando me dejo mi esposo pensé que nunca podía salir adelante, pero desD. que llego Finca Perú, me dio una oportunidad D. nacer nuevamente y dieron ideas D. negocio y ahora me va bien y L. plata D. finca me da mucha suerte”. A Marcelina le gustaria comprarse una casa, por que vive en casa alquilada.
texts.en:
The San José D. Sucre community is located some 30 minutes from the district of Cangallo. In this community, most people grow fruits and alfalfa for a living, but the production of grains is small and most people own businesses.

Irma Agüero sells fruit in Huancapi and Cangallo. She also raises guinea pigs and sells grains. Irma likes to have her own vehicle in order to improve her fruit orchards. Irma learned how to save at her microfinance institute.

Olga Gutiérrez owns a mini market. She also provides meals for highway workers and teachers. She wants to improve her business and save money for her children’s education with this loan.

Marcelina P. sells seven-seed chicha (a drink maD. from maize, wheat, barley, and garbanzo beans). She also runs a mini market. Marcelina dreams of moving forward along with her children. She states, “When my husband left me, I thought that I would never be able to get ahead, but ever since Finca Perú came along, I was given a chance to be reborn. They gave me business advice and now I am prosperous. The money that I get from Finca brings me a lot of luck.” Marcelina would like to buy her own home because she is currently renting one.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business capital for 10 members

loans.name: Amabel

texts.es:
La señora Amabel M. Vásquez tiene treintaiocho años de edad y vive en  barrio Los Pinos distrito de Mache provincia de Otuzco departamento de La Libertad Perú.
Estudió educación primaria completa pero no pudo continuar estudiando debido a la falta de apoyo económico de sus padres, pues en ese tiempo había que ir a continuar estudios en otro lugar porque en su distrito solamente había primaria.
Se casó muy joven con Carlos Haro con  el que tienen cinco hijos, una hija ya es casada y sus cuatro hijos son todavía estudiantes.
Su negocio consiste en la compra venta de trigo, cebada, chocho y menestras de la estación, lo realiza en su misma casa.
Con el primer préstamo que le dio Manuela Ramos que fue de 300 soles, compró trigo, cebada y chocho o tarwi como se conoce comúnmente. Su préstamo fue devuelto en cuatro meses.
Con este préstamo de S/ 300 soles con lo que comprará trigo y chocho o tarwi.  Este préstamo será cancelado en cuatro meses.
Pertenece al Banco Comunal Progresistas, es una socia muy activa y manifiesta que lo que más le gusta de los Bancos de Manuela Ramos son las reuniones porque se tratan temas de género.
Sueña y añora con una casa propia y que sus hijos lleguen a ser felices.
texts.en:
Mrs. Amabel M. Vásquez is a 38-year-old-woman who lives in the Los Pinos neighborhood of the Mache district in the Otuzco province, department of La Libertatd Perú. She completed elementary school but was unable to continue her studies due to a lack of financial support from her parents. At that time, she had to continue her studies outside her district because they only had an elementary school there. She married Carlos Haro, with whom she has 5 children, at a young age. One of her daughters is married, while her other four children are still in school. Her business consists of buying and selling grains such as wheat, barley, Andean lupin beans, and seasonal legumes from her own home. She was able to purchase wheat, barley, and Andean lupin beans—commonly known as “tarwi”—with the first loan of 300 PEN that she obtained from Manuela Ramos. Her loan was repaid in 4 months. With this loan of 300 PEN, she will purchase wheat and lupin beans. The loan will be repaid in 4 months. She is a member of the Progresistas (Progressives) microfinance institute. She is an active member, stating that what she likes most about the Manuel Ramos institutes are the meetings because they are about relevant topics. She dreams of owning her own home and making her children happy.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of wholesale grains

loans.name: Gloria Genoveva

texts.es:
La señora Gloria Genoveva R. T. tiene treintaiocho años de edad y vive en el caserío La Primavera, distrito de Mache, provincia de Julcán departamento de La Libertad  Perú.
Gloria estudió hasta el cuarto año de primaría lo que ahora equivale a quinto grado, no continuo estudiando debido a la falta de apoyo económica de sus padres.
Se casó a los dieciocho años con el señor Amado Ibáñez Rodríguez con quien tienen cinco hijos de los cuales una hija se casó y los otros cuatro son estudiantes.
Se dedica a la compra venta de animales menores, como conejos y cuyes, también cría cerdos y compra y vende quesos y quesillos.
Con el primer préstamo que le brindo Manuela R. que fue de 300 soles, recuerda que compró cuyes y conejos, devolvió el préstamo en cuatro meses.
Con este préstamo de S/. 1000 soles con los que comprará una oveja y cuyes.  Este crédito será devuelto en cuatro meses.
Pertenece al Comedor Popular Corazón de Jesús de Primavera y al Banco Comunal Mujeres de Trabajo, es una socia muy cumplida en ambas organizaciones.
Sueña con tener su propio capital y ayudar a sus demás compañeras.
texts.en:
Mrs. Gloria Genoveva R. T. is 38 years old and lives in La Primavera village, Mache district, Julcán province of La Libertad state in Peru. Gloria finished fourth year of primary school which is now the equivalent of fifth grade. She didn’t continue studying because her parents did not have the economic resources to pay for schooling. She married at 18 years old to Mr. Amado Ibáñez Rodríguez, they have five children, with one daughter who is married and the other four are students. She buys and sells small animals such as rabbits and guinea pigs, she also raises pigs and buys chese and quesillos (cheese wrapped in banana leaves). With the first loan Manuela R. loaned her for 300 soles, she remembers that she bought guinea pigs and rabbits, and repaid the loan within 4 months. With this laon for S/. 1000 soles she will buy a sheep and guinea pigs. This loan will be repaid over 4 months. She belongs to the Communal Kitchen “Corazón de Jesús de Primavera” and to the Communal Bank “Mujeres de Trabajo,” and she is an accomplished member in both organizations. She dreams of having her own money and helping her colleagues.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy small animals

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es: La señora M. B., tiene 41 años de edad, es casada, habita en el municipio de san Jacinto poblado ubicado a unos 12 kilometros del poblado de telica tambine municipio de leon, sus hijos tienen de edad 11 años, 9 años y 7 años respectivamente, todos estudian la primaria en un colegio publico, el esposo de la señora es agricultor, La señora pretende mejorar sus condiciones de vida, por consiguiente ayudar a sus hijos a salir adelante y herdearles una carrera como profesionales, La actividad economica de la señora es una pulperia ubicada en su casa de habitacion donde ofrece una variedad de productos del hogar como gaseosa, aroos, azucar , aceite , frijoles, queso, pollo, papel higienico entre otros productos, doña Maria Elena, da inicio en este actividad como una necesidad de empleo y subsitencia que con el paso de los años ha venido tomando como su fuente de trabajo y con la cual aporta a los gastos del hogar y estudios de los hijos.
texts.en:
Mrs. M. B. is 41 years old, is married, and lives in the town of San Jacinto located some 12 kilometers from the village of Telica Tambine, Leon. Her children are 11 years old, 9 years old, and 7 years old, respectively. All of them are in a public elementary school. Her husband is a farmer. She tries to improve the conditions of her life, in order to help her children to go forward and to bequeath them a career as professionals. Mrs. M. B. owns a grocery store located in her home, where she offers a variety of home products like soda, rice, sugar, oil, beans, cheese, chicken, and toilet paper, among other products. Mrs. Maria Elena began this activity as a necessity for employment and subsistence. With the passing of the years, this activity has given her a fountain of work and allows her to contribute to the expenses of the home and her children’s education.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital for her work

loans.name: Maritza Del Rosario

texts.es: La señora S. H., es una mujer emprendedora que tiene 29 años de edad, es casada, tiene tres hijos con edades comprendidas entre los los dos, cuatro y cino años respectivamente, cursando dos de ellos el preecolar y el otro el segundo grado su hijo menor no estudia todavia, su compañero de vida no esta trabajando de manera fija sino por trabajos eventuales que le salen, la actividad economica de la señora es la comercializacion de ropa nueva en genral y cosmeticos, en el municipio de malpaisillo, teniendo 6 años de dedicarse a esta actividad, la señora da inicio como toda persona con la necesidad de subsistir y poder llevar el pan a su familia, ya que los ingresos de su esposo no son fijos, Doña Maritza tiene como proposito ser una distrbuidora al por mayor de mercaderia como ropa nueva y comseticos y mas adelante instalar una tienda, así como mejorar su vivienda de esta manera brindarle un poco mas de condicones a su familia.
texts.en:
Mrs. S. H. is an enterprising woman, who is 29 years old and is married. She has three chidren, who are 2 years old, 4 years old, and 5 years old, respectively. Two of them are in nursery school and the other is second grade. The youngest child doesn’t study yet. Her partner doesn’t have a fixed job; instead, he has temporary jobs. Mrs. S. H. markets new clothes and cosmetics in the town of Malpaisillo. She has spent 6 years pursuing this activity. She began this business because of the need to subsist and to be the breadwinner in the family, since her husband’s earnings aren’t fixed. Mrs. Maritza aims to be a distributor of wholesale merchandise like new clothes and cosmetics. She would also like to set up a store in the future, and improve her home, and, in this way, offer better conditions to her family.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital for her work

loans.name: Orn

texts.en:
Mrs. Orn S., 42, and her husband, Mr. Phon So, are farmers growing rice. They live in Korkthlokleu Commune, Siem Reap Province. Orn S. has been growing rice since 1980 and earns around 5,000 Riel (US$1.25). Orn has five children, some of whom still live at home with the family.

Two of their children are employed as construction workers and left home to work in the Siem Reap Province. Their income also helps to support the family. Because of her difficulty with growing rice, Orn S. would like to request a loan of 2,000,000 Riel (US$ 500) to purchase two oxen to use for plowing their farmland. Any remainder she plans to spend on farming activities such as transplanting rice seedlings and fertilizer.

loans.use: To purchase two oxen for plowing farmland and pay expenses for transplanting rice seedlings and fertilizer

loans.name: Mrs. Chok Savorn Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Chok S. is the group leader of five who all live in Kor Village in Kandal Province. She is a garment factory worker who can earn $75 per month while her husband, Mr. Long Saroeun, owns a lumber mill in the local village. They have a child who is yet too young to attend school.

Even though Chok and her husband have different businesses, they cannot afford to build a much-needed new house for their family. Thus, she is requesting a loan to add to her savings for its construction in order to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to add to her saving in order to build it for her household.

loans.name: Mrs. Sat Kunthea Group

texts.en: The four people in this group live in Andong Village in Kandal Province. Mrs. Sat K. is the group leader. She owns a small restaurant where she sells Chinese noodles to villagers and travelers. Her husband, Mr. Sri Roeurn, assists her. Mrs. Sat K. has a child who attends the local school. Although Mrs. Sat K. and her husband try to work hard, they still live in a leaking house. To solve this problem, Mrs. Sat K. is asking for a loan to fix her house.

loans.use: To repair her house.

loans.name: Mrs. Sok Sovannara Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank, consisting of nine people living in Preak Ta Aek Village in Kandal Province, is led by 38-year-old Village Bank President Mrs. S. S., the mother of three children who are all attending the local school. She is a mat maker who can make $6 per day, and since her business is doing well, she is requesting a loan to buy more raw materials to make more mats in order to meet customer demand. Her husband, Mr. Duong Kea, is a motorbike taxi driver who can make $3 per day, a small income that nonetheless contributes to the family’s support.

This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. Two members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Theses members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor, allowing them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials to make more mats in order to meet customer demand.

loans.name: Ni Nengah Tarmin

texts.id: Ni Nengah Tarmin seorang ibu rumah tangga yang mempunyai pekerjaan sampingan memelihara babi. Pekerjaan tersebut ditekuninya untuk menambah pendapatan  keluarganya, khususnya untuk meringankan beban suaminya dalam memenuhi perekonomian keluarganya. Sebelumnya, Ni Nengah Tarmin menjalani usaha ini hanya untuk mengisi waktu luang di rumah. Namun setelah mendapat pembinaan dan pelatihan tentang beternak babi dari Yayasan Dinari, Ni Nengah Tarmin ingin meningkatkan usahanya. Untuk mewujudkan hal tersebut, Ni Nengah Tarmin bergabung dengan program Dinari, khususnya program Ternak Babi yang periode pinjamannya selama 6 bulan dan pembayaran pinjaman pada akhir periode. Hal tersebut berdasarkan perhitungan masa pemeliharaan babi selama 4 – 5 bulan dan bulan ke 6, peternak sudah siap menjual babinya. Dengan bergabungnya Ni Nengah Tarmin ke dalam program tersebut, ia berhak mendapat pendampingan  Dokter Hewan dari Yayasan Dinari dan mendapat pelatihan mendalam tentang beternak babi. Pinjaman yang didapat direncanakan untuk membeli induk dan anak babi untuk meningkatkan populasi ternaknya. Ni Nengah Tarmin optimis usahanya akan maju dengan adanya bantuan dana dan pendampingan dari Dinari.
texts.en:
Ni Nengah Tarmin is a housewife. She raises piglets to help the family's economic. She received guidances from DINARI Foundation in the field of pig farming. She is now in a 6 month pig farming program from DINARI Foundation. She hopes she can buy more breeding pigs and piglets to improve her business.


Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy breeding pigs and piglets (Membeli induk dan anak babi)

loans.name: Ni Nengah Karsini

texts.id: Setiap orang pasti memiliki keinginan untuk mengubah standar kehidupannya menjadi lebih baik. Hal ini terjadi juga dalam kehidupan Ni Nengah Karsini, ibu dengan seorang anak yang saat ini berusia 10 tahun dan masih mengenyam pendidikan di Sekolah Dasar. Keinginan tersebut muncul setelah melihat keberhasilan tetangganya menjadi peternak babi setelah mendapat binaan dan bantuan dana dari Dinari dan Kiva. Walaupun tingkat pendidikan yang dimilikinya masih sangat rendah, namun semangat dan keinginannya untuk meningkatkan perekonomian keluarganya sangat besar. Ni Nengah Karsini memutuskan untuk bergabung dengan program Yayasan Dinari,  khususnya program Ternak Babi yang periode pinjamannya selama 6 bulan dan pembayaran pinjaman pada akhir periode. Hal tersebut berdasarkan perhitungan masa pemeliharaan babi selama 4 – 5 bulan dan bulan ke 6, peternak sudah siap menjual babinya. Pinjaman yang didapatnya dipergunakan untuk membeli induk babi dan pakan. Ni Nengah Karsini berencana untuk menjual anak babi yang dipelihara selama 2 bulan. Induk babi yang sekarang sudah mempunyai 5 ekor anak dan 2 bulan ke depan bisa dijual dengan harga Rp. 300.000.- per ekor. Induk babi yang akan dibelinya akan dipersiapkan untuk masa panen berikutnya. Ni Nengah Karsini sangat bersyukur ia dapat bergabung dalam program ini dan ia pun bangga karena dapat memberi sumbangan untuk kebutuhan keluarganya.
texts.en:
Ni Nengah Karsi is a mother of a 10 old kid. She is inspired by her neighbor's success in pig farming business. She wants to follow her neighbor's footstep so she can also improve her family's welfare.

She joined the DINARI Foundation program where she is raising piglets for a 6 month period. Her breeding pig is now having 5 piglets that she can sell for IDR 300 thousand (around USD 32)/ pig in 2 months time.

She really hopes to be able to improve her economic condition by joining this program.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy breeding pig (Membeli induk)

loans.name: Ni Made Wiratna

texts.id: Sudah menjadi tradisi, setiap masyarakat Bali, khususnya ibu rumah tangga memelihara babi di rumahnya. Kebanyakan dari mereka memelihara babi hanya sebagai pekerjaan sampingan karena masih sedikit yang mengerti tentang beternak babi yang baik dan benar. Ni Made Wiratna bergabung dengan program ternak babi dari Yayasan Dinari yang masa pinjamannya selama 6 bulan dan pengembalian pinjaman pada akhir periode. Ni Made Wiratna ingin menjadi peternak babi yang sukses dengan mendapat pendampingan dari Yayasan Dinari. Dengan modal sendiri yang dimilikinya, Ni Made Wiratna membangun kandang yang terdiri dari 3 kamar. Dengan pinjaman yang didapatnya, Ni Made Wiratna berencana membeli anak babi yang akan dipeliharanya selam 3 bulan dan akan dijual kembali untuk babi guling. Hal itu dipilihnya karena perputaran modalnya lebih cepat. Suaminya sangat mendukung usaha yang ditekuninya ini dan siap membantu setiap saat. Ni Made Wiratna sangat bahagia karena selain mendapat pendampingan dan dana, keluarganya pun sangat mendukungnya. Ia berharap usahanya akan sukses dan tetap meminta pendampingan dari Dinari.
texts.en:
Pig farming is a traditional side occupation for many Balinese housewives. However, only few of these farmers understand proper farming techniques. Ni Made Wiratna joined DINARI's pig farming program and also obtained a 6 month loan from the foundation. Ni Made Wiratna is hoping to increase the success of her farm, therefore, she sought technical help from DINARI foundation. With her own funding, she built 3 chamber pig pens. She plans to use the loan to purchase 3 piglets that will be kept and grown for 3 months then sold as slaughter pigs. She picked this segment due to the relatively quick cash cycle. Her husband is very supportive to her business and ready to help. Ni Made Wiratna is very happy because in addition to technical and funding help from DINARI, she also gets her family's support. She is hoping her success will continue with DINARi's help.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase Piglets

loans.name: Siem

texts.en:
Mrs. Siem B., 25, sells chickens in the market. She buys them from raisers, who live in Toek Thla in the Banteay Meanchey Province. She travels with her husband to villagers' homes to purchase chickens and then sells them at the market.

Siem B.'s husband, Mr. Sophy Pen, 37, is a motorcycle taxi driver. Mrs. Siem has two children, both in school. With her growing business, Siem needs the capital to expand her business by purchasing more chickens to sell. She would like to request a loan to add to her money to expand her chicken-selling business.

loans.use: To add to her money to expand her chicken-selling business

loans.name: Mr. Men Kchey Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of five people living in Khsom Village in Kandal Province who plan to use the loan for various purposes. Mr. Men K., a house constructor, is the group leader while his wife, Mrs. Phon Nhorn, owns a small grocery store in the local village. They have five children, one a garment factory worker, three construction workers, and the youngest a student.

Although Mr. Men K. and his wife have different businesses, they still live in an old house in poor conditions. In order to improve the family’s standard of living, Men is requesting a loan to add to his savings to build a new house.

loans.use: To add to his savings to build a new house.

loans.name: Mrs. Nov Rours Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank, located in Angk Village in Kandal Province, consists of eight members who will use the loan for a variety of purposes. For example, Mrs. Nov R., the Village Bank President, is a fisherwoman requesting a loan to buy a new boat in order to restart her business which has been sidelined due to the unseaworthiness of her current boat. Her husband, Mr. Tong Pheng, assists in her business.

Nov is 42 years old and the mother of six children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while another two help their parents and do housework. The remaining two are attending the local school. This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. Five members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor, allowing them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a new boat in order to restart her business.

loans.name: Mrs. Seng Mali Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Seng M., a group leader of four who all live in Srae Ampil Village in Kandal Province, is a cow breeder currently raising 20 cows. In order to improve her standard of living, she is requesting a loan to add to her savings to build a new house for her household.

Seng is a 59-year-old widow with four children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while another one is a carpenter. The youngest is enrolled in the local school. Although Seng and her children have different livelihoods, they still live in an old house under poor conditions.

loans.use: To add to her savings to build a new house for her household.

loans.name: Soeu

texts.en:
Mrs. Soeu Y. is 26 years old and married with two children. She owns a stand near her town selling baby duck-eggs to people passing through. A baby-duck egg boiled up to 100 Celsius tastes very delicious and it's awesome with the tastes of liquid inside the egg. With her business activity, she can make around US$ 6/day of net income.

Moreover, Soeu Y.'s husband runs a carpentry shop producing wooden items such as tables, chairs, cabinets, wardrobes, and so on and he can typically make about US$ 10 each day in gross income.

Mrs. Soeu Y. has applied for a loan to expand her business. Any leftover money will be used to purchase a motor-bike to use for her business transportation needs.

loans.use: To expand her business and purchase a motor-bike to use for her business transportation

loans.name: Mrs. Kem Ny Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank, located in Chrouy Dang Village, consists of 22 people led by Village Bank President Mrs. Kem N., a farmer who cultivates both rice and vegetables. She is requesting a loan to purchase more vegetable seeds to grow in her field. Her husband, Mr. Em Muon, is a construction worker whose small income helps to support the family.

Kem has six children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while another is a construction worker. The remaining three are attending the local school. Two of the men shown in the photo are representing their wives who were unavailable due to work commitments.

This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. Three members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay aN. principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor, allowing them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments maN. months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetable seeds to grow in her field.

loans.name: Mrs. Heng Khom Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This Village Bank loan consists of eight members in Khsach Village in Kandal Province led by Village Bank President Mrs. H. K., a vegetable farmer requesting a loan to purchase more vegetable seeds to cultivate in her field. Her husband, Mr. En Korn, assists his wife's business in order to improve their living conditions together.

H. is 44 years old and the mother of four children, one a poultry breeder and another a boat operator who makes a small income that helps support the family. The other two children attend the local school.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetable seeds to cultivate.

loans.name: Mrs. Chan Pao Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank consists of ten people and is located in Toul Meas Village in Kandal Province. The bank plans to use the loan that it obtained for different purposes. Mrs. Chan P. is the village bank president and is a vegetable seller who can generate $5 of an income a day. Since her business is going well, Mrs. Chan P. has decided to ask for a loan to buy additional vegetables to re-sell for her customers. Her husband, Mr. Proeung Korng, helps her business. Mrs. Chan P. is 56 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is a constructiO. worker and the youngest one is attending the local school.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Four members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal O. the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments O. time.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to re-sell for her customers.

loans.name: Mout

texts.en:
Mrs. Mout R., 54, is a widow and works as a rice farmer. A few months ago, her crops faced a problem of insects destroying almost sixty percent of her crop. As a result, what she could make was just barely enough to cover her entire family's living expenses.

Fortunately, one of her son can earns about US$ 4/day working in construction and another one makes around US$ 3 each day working as a laborer at a dock. Together they can help her handle her entire family's living expenses.

Hearing about CREDIT MFI from her neighbor, Mrs. Mout R. has recently applied for a loan in the amount of US$ 800 to purchase insecticide, fertilizer and seeds to expand her crops and make her crops safe from insects. She believes that this year she will gain much more rice output than before. ( Her son who works in construction is pictured because Mrs. Mout R. was not available.)

loans.use: To buy insecticide, fertilizer, and seeds to expand her crop yield

loans.name: Mrs. Chea Sa Koen Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Chea S. K. is the group leader of four who all live in Ruessei Srok Village in Kandal Province. She is a farmer who owns 0.5 hectares where she cultivates rice. In her rice field, she now faces a small problem because her field is infertile which negatively affects her crop. In order to solve this obstacle, Mrs. Chea S. K. has decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizers to support her field to make her crop more productive. Her husband, Mr. Sam Bunthoeurn, is a fisherman who gathers little fish to sell. Mrs. Chea S. K. is 37 years old and the mother of four children who are all enrolled in the local school.

This is a group loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Two members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers to support her field to make her crops more productive.

loans.name: Sen

texts.en:
Mrs. Sen C., 19, is a grocery seller. She sells many types of products from her house such as cake, candy, food ingredients, and cosmetics. All the products are bought from the market in Siem Reap town. She typically earns around US$ 5 per day, while her husband, Mr. Samol Kha, 20, sells chopped wood from the forest and he can earn around US$ 3.30 per day.

Sen lives with her husband and one child in Peaksneng Commune in the Siem Reap Province. Because of increasing customer demand, Sen needs to expand her inventory and add other products to satisfy her customers, but she faces the obstacle of lacking money to carry out this project. Hence, she would like to request a loan of US$ 1,000 to carry out her plan.

loans.use: To expand her inventory to satisfy her customers

loans.name: Thorng

texts.en:
Mrs. Thorng K., age 26, is married with one little child. She works with her husband farming rice and raising a few pigs, making collectively about $2.50 of income each day. However, growing rice is not a good option and the income is not nearely enough to cover her entire family's expenses. The inflation rate is out of control, so the price of goods has increased as well. 

In order to maintain her living condition, Mrs. Thorng K. has applied for a loan of $1000 to purchase more piglets and cows to breed. She will be able to sell them for profit in about six to seven months. 

Her husband is pictured because Mrs. Thorng K. wa not available.

loans.use: To buy piglets and cows to breed

loans.name: Yang

texts.en: Mrs. Yang D., 38, is married with four children and has a stand at a market where she sells a variety of vegetables, making around $3 each day. Her husband works as a sculptor and typically earns around $5 per day. In order to fulfill her client's needs, Mrs. Yang D. would like to request a loan to expand her inventory and to buy a motorbike for her husband to commute to work.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband to commute to work

loans.name: Vann

texts.en:
Mrs. Vann R., 31, is a mother of two little children ages 8 and 4. She works as a rice farmer making about $2.50 each day from selling her rice to a market. Her husband sells firewood that he buys from a distant market and resells in different locations around his town. He can typically makes around $3 to $4 of profit each day from his firewood busines. 

Mrs. Van R. would like to ask for a loan to purchase more seeds to expand her crops. She will use the remainder of the loan to purchase more firewood for her husband so that he can increase his profit.

loans.use: To buy more seeds to expand her crops and purchase more firewood to sell.

loans.name: Ismayil

texts.en: Ismayil M., 35, is married and has two children. He is a policeman in the Bilasuvar region where is living now. His main financial income comes from selling dairy products as milk and yoghurt to the local people and factories. He started his business in 1999 when his family conditions were very bad and his salary wasn't enough to purchase the necessary food products. With the help of his relatives, he built a good business. But time passed, prices for everything increased, and his business needs to expand. For this purpose Ismayil applied for a loan of $1200 USD.

loans.use: to purchase two milkier cows

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali Q. is a 44-year-old farmer, and is married with 2 children. He is proactive and a very ambitious person. He is working hard in the sheep and livestock business, and he has an education in agronomy. This education helped him when he decided to engage in this business in 1989.

Ali has applied for a loan of $1200 USD. He will use this money to purchase an additional cow for $600 and 10 sheep for $60 each. He wants to earn more income so he can provide his children with a good education and improve their lives. This loan would help him accomplish his goals in a short time.

loans.use: To purchase 10 sheep and one cow

loans.name: Mohammad Halam

texts.en:
M. Halam is 19 years old. He is single and he just finished school. He has a retail shop where he works with one of his older brothers. He likes a lot working in the retail shop. Therefore, when he was trying to enlarge this business, he found AFSG in Kabul.

He requested an individual loan to buy more inventory for his shop and change his business by expanding it. He would like to be a good shopkeeper in the future to make bright future.

He is happy. After one or two years, he wants to open anther shop for his big brother. He wants to be a good client for Kiva and AFSG and would love to continue his partnership. He would like to thank lenders.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for his shop

loans.name: Solmaz

texts.en: Solmaz Q., 56, is a very active and passionate woman. She started her business in 1986 and since that time she's become a well-experienced and skilled woman and many people of her village come to ask her advice about keeping livestock. Her primary activity is to sell dairy products and calves for meat production. Solmaz find herself more dedicated to selling dairy products and she would like to expand her activity in this filed. For this purpose, she applied for a loan of $800 USD. She will use this loan to purchase a cow for milking. Let's help her reach her goals!

loans.use: To purchase a cow for milking

loans.name: Ismet

texts.en:
Ismet H. is a 50-year-old man who is the loving father of two adorable children, one son and one daughter. They are both university students and Ismet tries very hard to cover their needs while they are students.

Ismet has been selling livestock and dairy products as a primary business since 1997. He provides the markets with meat and his family with the necessary food. At the same time, he is working as a teacher in the local school.

Ismet wants to buy one cow for 600 USD and two calves for 300 USD each. He wants to earn more income so he can provide his children with a good education and improve their lives. This amount would help him accomplish his goals in a short time. Your generosity can change their lives.

loans.use: to purchase one cow and two calves

loans.name: Toribia

texts.es:
Toribia, D. 53 años D. edad, se dedica desD. hace mucho tiempo a la venta D. comida. 

Ella se levanta muy temprano por las mañanas para preparar los desayunos, que luego 
sale a vender a las calles. Algunas veces sus vecinas van a su casa a comprar las cosas 
que ella prepara, como por ejemplo los tamales; otras veces ella recorre las casas ofreciendo
 los desayunos a precios muy económicos. 

Los préstamos que anteriormente ha recibido Toribia le ayudaron a poder comprar insumos
para preparar la comida que ella venD..

A ella le gustaría tener más facilidades para poder adquirir en mayor cantidad los insumos que 
ella requiere para preparar los desayunos que venD., y así poder ahorrar algo D. dinero.
texts.en:
Toriba is 53 years old. For a long time she has worked selling food. She gets up very early in the mornings in order to prepare breakfasts that later she heads out to sell in the streets. Some times her neighbors come by her house to buy the things that she makes, for example her tamales; other times she walks from house to house offering the breakfast at very economical prices. The loans that she has received before have helped her be able to buy ingredients in order to prepare the food that she sells. She would like to have more facilities in order to be able to get ingredients she needs to prepare breakfasts in larger quantities, and so be able to save some money.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Comprar insumos para continuar y ampliar su negocio de venta de comida.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Faiq

texts.en:
Faiq S. is a 43-year-old man who breeds sheep in Bilasuvar region. He is married with 6 children. It is difficult to keep such a large family in good conditions, but Faiq is working very hard to improve his family's living conditions. His older children help him with looking after the sheep.

Faiq has applied for a $1000 USD loan to purchase 15 sheep for $60 USD each, and fodder for the rest for $100 USD.

loans.use: To purchase sheep and fodder

loans.name: Long

texts.en:
Long S., aged 26, is married and resides with one little child in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 2003, she has been employed as a garment worker to earn a living and is able to make US$ 2 each day. Her husband, Vat Vann, 25, is a construction worker building houses. On average, he makes US$ 3 per day.

Working as a builder is hard and he earns little to support the family. Long has requested a loan of US$ 1100 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate a motor-taxi as currently construction work is unstable. A motor-taxi business will increase the family income. (Long is pictured with her husband.)

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate a motor-taxi

loans.name: Chuy

texts.en: Chuy S., 35, is a good housewife who stays at home cooking food for her family members. She also owns a plot of farmland where she grows rice to earn a living and is able to make US$4 each day. Her husband, Lach Leang, 32, is a cow dealer and typically earns US$13 in revenue each day. This couple has three children, one of whom is a student and the other two are too young to attend school. Chuy is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase cows for her husband's business.

loans.use: To purchase cows.

loans.name: Bibinazira

texts.en: Bibinazira J. is 38 years old. She is married and the loving mother of three children. All her children are in school. Bibinazira's husband is a driver and his income is very low; that is why she decided to start her own business so that she could help him cover their living expenses. For more than 10 years she has been selling clothing for children. Bibinazira is a very enthusiastic and dynamic woman. She has very nice taste in picking the clothing she buys and amazing marketing skills in convincing her clients about the clothing they should buy. Bibinazira has been the main breadwinner of the family for a long time. She now needs a loan of 3000 Somoni ($900 USD), which she will use to buy new clothing for the autumn season. She promises to repay the loan within six months. Bibinazira is thankful for your generosity and help.

loans.use: To purchasing new clothing

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok K., 38, is married and has four young children. The family lives in the Kampong Cham province. She grows sugar cane, typically making $1 USD each day. Her husband, Nan Oeun, is a construction worker who typically makes about $3 USD each day. 

Sok K. would like a loan of $300 USD to purchase a cow to breed. This loan would allow for their family to increase their profits from raising the animal along with their daily income.

loans.use: To purchase a cow.

loans.name: Sitha

texts.en:
Mrs. Sitha S., 42, and her husband, Mr. Vei Nop, are farmers who grow rice in Svay At Commune, Pursat Province. Sitha has been growing rice since 1979 and currently earns around US$2.5 per day. She has seven children, one of whom is married. One of her children is photographer who works far from home and the remaining five live at home and go to school. 

To reduce difficulty of her farming activities, she would like to request a loan of US$1,000. With part of the loan, she will purchase buffaloes to use as draft animals to plow their farmland. She will use the remainder of the loan to purchase a cart that the buffaloes can pull for transportation.

Mrs. Sitha's husband is pictured because Sitha was not available.

loans.use: To purchase buffaloes to plow their farmland and a cart for the buffaloes to pull

loans.name: Ben

texts.en:
Ben L., age 31, is married and lives in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 2002, she has been selling fermented fish and sugar cane. She transports the goods out of her village and sells to other villages. Normally, she makes US$ 2.50 each day. Her husband, Hean Sokha, is a motor-taxi driver and is able to make US$ 2.50 per day as well.

This couple together has three children and all of them are students. Ben L. would like to take out a loan of US$ 500 to increase her fermented fish and sugar cane sales. In the future, she plans to own a grinding mill for extra profit to support the family. For her children, she wants them at least to complete high school. (Hean Sokha and a daughter are pictured because Ben L. was was not available.)

loans.use: To purchase more fermented fish and sugar cane for re-sale

loans.name: Firuza

texts.en: Firuza K. is 41 years old. She is married and has six children. Her husband has no fixed job, so Firuza must work to support her large family's needs. She worked fortwo years in a gift shop, and thanks to her savings, six years ago she was able to start her own business. She now sells clothing for children. She gets help from her children, who take care of the store in the afternoon. Thanks to her hard work, her customers increased and she had to rent the store next door to expand and offer a better variety. She is now requesting a loan of $1000 USD, which she will use to buy new clothing for the autumn season. She commits to repay the loan over a period of 12 months. Firuza is thankful for your generosity and help.

loans.use: Purchasing of the new clothing for increasing the range of goods.

loans.name: Lidia

texts.es:
Lidia tiene 52 años. ElL. desD. hace algunos años se dedica a L. confección D. prendas D. vestir, en el pequeño taller que ha puesto en su casa. 

Lidia se dedica a tiempo completo a su negocio D. confección D. ropa. Su hija menor le ayuda cuando tiene algo D. tiempo, ya que elL. está estudiando en una universidad pública.

Con el préstamo que anteriormente recibió Lidia pudo comprar telas e hilos para confeccionar L. ropa que elL. venD..

A elL. le gustaría comprar un carrito sanguchero, así elL. podría vender comida por las noches en L. puerta D. su casa, y tener algo más D. ingresos para su familia.
texts.en:
Lidia is 52 years old. For some years she has maD. clothing in a small workshop she has in her home.

Lidia works full time in her business making clothing. Her youngest daughter helps her when she has a bit of time, since she is studying in a public university.

With a prior loan Lidia was able to buy fabric and thread to make the clothing she sells.

She would like to buy a vending cart so that she can sell food at night from her front door and have more income for her family.


Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a vending cart for selling food.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Luon

texts.en:
Luon S., 37, is an impoverished entrepreneur and has a business selling fish in her village. Every morning she receives fish from her husband who works as a fisherman and then transports it on her bicycle and sells it from house to house. She typically makes about US$ 2.5 each day.

Her husband, Penh Kim, sometimes catches more fish and he also sells it to fishmongers after he provides some to his wife. This couple has four children, two of whom are students; two others are employed as garment workers. Luon is requesting a loan of US$ 500 to purchase more fishing implements so her husband can catch more fish.

loans.use: To purchase more fishing implements for her husband

loans.name: Oykhol

texts.en:
Oykhol K. is 43 years old. She is married and the loving mother of 4 children. She started her own business 13 years ago because her husband’s salary was not enough for their family expenses.

Oykhol is a market entrepreneur from Shahrituz, Tajikistan. She runs a stall selling candies and sweets. The inventory she has for sale is of very good quality and she offers a wide selection. Oykhol is respectful and patient with all of her customers which attracts people and brings them back to her vending facility to buy her goods again.

Oykhol is seeking to keep her business sustainable and has requested a loan of 3500 Somoni (1025 USD) for a term of 6 months to increase the inventory she has for sale. One of her plans for the future is to open a new vending facility. We believe this current loan will enhance the potential of her business and help Oykhol reach all of her aspirations.

loans.use: Enlarging her range of goods and purchasing of an individual store

loans.name: Mrs. Tork Ly Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank consists of 29 people and is located in Traeuy Troeng Village in Kandal Province; they plan to use the loan differentL.. For instance, Mrs. Tork L. is the village bank president who is a pig breeder and raises ten pigs. Since her pigs are growing bigger and bigger, she does not have enough money to buy pig food to feed her pigs. Thus, Mrs. Tork L. has decided to ask for a loan to invest in more food for her animals. Her husband, Mr. Lin Nget, is a farmer who owns a hectare to cultivate rice. Mrs. Tork L. is 55 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is a rice wine maker while the others are attending the local school. The three men who are in the picture are requesting the loan on behalf of their wives.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainL. end-of-term loans. One member has end-of-term loans and the rest have monthL. payment loans. This member is not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financialL. able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time.

loans.use: To buy pig food to feed her pigs.

loans.name: Malika

texts.en:
Malika M. is 51 years. She is married with 4 children. Malika is an older woman who is working hard to reach a better lifestyle and rise out of poverty. Despite of her ripe old age, her energy shines in her activity.

Malika has a large family with several grandchildren. Since 1994, she has been engaged in bicycle spare parts sales. She has a stall in the local market. She sells spare parts of different types and for various bicycles. As a result of the success of her business, Malika has improved the living conditions of her family and is doing her best to meet all the needs of her dearest grandchildren.

Now she is not satisfied with the volume of sales and wants to increase her stock of inventory, thus increasing the volume of sales. With this purpose today Malika requests 3500 Somoni (1025 USD) for a term of 6 months. She is planning to spend the loan purchasing spare parts for bicycles so as to increase her range of goods. With your help this will be possible. Be an important part of the growth of Malika’s business.

loans.use: Purchasing spare parts for bicycles to increase her range of goods

loans.name: Mrs. Kang Sophy Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank in Traeuy Troeng Village in the Kandal Province has 27 members. Mrs. Kang S. is the village bank president. She owns a small grocery store in the local village. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it so she has decided to ask for a loan to buy additional grocery products for her inventory. Aside from this business, she is a recycle collector who gathers empty bottles, cans and plastic. Mrs. Kang S. is a 37-year-old widow wI. a child who is employed in a garment factory.  She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions wI. this loan.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products for her store.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en: Halima Y. is a dynamic 55-year-old mother. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a teacher, but his salary is very low and insufficient to cover the costs of living and school for their kids. Faced with the need for another income, Halima began to sell shoes eight years ago. Little by little, thanks to her passion for making sales and her personality, she has been increasing her number of clients and making her business grow. At this moment, Halima needs a loan of 2500 Somoni ($750 USD) that she will invest in purchasing more merchandise to meet the demands of her clients. She promises to repay this loan in six months. Halima is honest and has reimbursed all her previous loans in a timely manner. Help Halima improve her family's quality of life by contributing to the growth of her business. They thank you sincerely.

loans.use: Purchasing new merchandise.

loans.name: Vesna

texts.en: Vesna I. ević, born in 1971, lives with her husband and two daughters in Gračanica, known as a very enterprising city. Her husband works on a poultry farm, a job that has given Vesna an idea to start her own business raising hens, as there is a good market for eggs. She is therefore requesting a loan of $750 for the purchase of hens. Vesna believes that her business will succeed, aided by her husband and his experience with poultry.

loans.use: To buy hens

loans.name: Abdul Bashir

texts.en:
A. Bashir is 50 years old, married, and has 3 children. He has worked for the government for a long time. He lives in a rental house because his salary is not large enough to build or buy a house. He wants to build a house but it is too difficult, so he wants to take out an individual loan to buy materials to build his house as soon as possible.

He wants to thank both kiva and AFSG. He is very happy that he is going to be the owner of a house at the end, and he wants to thank all lenders.

loans.use: To buy materials to build a house

loans.name: I Ketut Derta Yasa Saputra

texts.id:
I Ketut Derta Yasa Saputra tinggal bersama istri dan ke dua anaknya di Bjr. Tunas Mekar, Ds.Manistutu. Walaupun bekerja sebagai pegawai Negeri, penghasilannya tidak bisa mencukupi kebutuhan keluarganya. Hal ini disebabkan karena selain harus mencukupi kebutuhan ekonomi keluarga sehari-hari ia juga harus membiayai ke dua anaknya yang masih bersekolah yakni SMP dan SD. Untuk mencukupi biaya kebutuhan keluarganya I Ketut Derta Yasa Putra dengan di bantu istrinya memilih untuk beternak babi pengindukan. Dengan lahan dan kandang yang sederhana I Ketut Derta Yasa Putra memelihara 1 ekor induk babi dan dalam waktu 6 bulan ia sudah bisa menjual hasil ternaknya yaitu anak dari induk tersebut dengan sekali beranak bisa 6 sampai 8 ekor.
Untuk mengembangkan usahanya I Ketut Derta Yasa Putra mengikuti program ternak babi yang dikelola DINARI  dan mendapatkan pinjaman Rp. 1.500.000,-  dengan jangka waktu pinjaman satu tahun dan pembayaran dilakukan secara mencicil setiap bulan. Dengan tambahan modal tersebut I Ketut Derta Yasa Putra menggunakan untuk membeli pakan dan satu bibit babi lagi sehingga dia berharap usahanya bisa lebih maju dan kehidupan keluarganya bisa lebih baik.
texts.en:
I ketut Derta Yasa Saputra lives with his wife and 2 children in Manistutu Village. He works a s a government employee, however, his income is not sufficient to fulfill all his family's need. He needs to pay tuition for his 2 children that are in middle school and primary school. To pay for his daily family expenses, he with the help of his wife, he started a pig breeding business. With simple farming infrastructure, I ketut Derta Yasa Putra farmed 1 breeding pig, that produced 6-8 piglets that can be sold. To expand his business, I Ketut Derta Yasa Putra joined DINARI's farming program that provided him with funding and technical help. He is seeking $175 loan to be repaid monthly for 1 year. With that additional funding, I Ketut Derta Yasa Putra plans to purchase more feeds and an additional breeding pigs, so he can earn more profit and improve his family's economic situation.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase feeds and pigs

loans.name: Ni Ketut Astuti

texts.id: Dalam menghadapi situasi ekonomi yang semakin sulit seperti sekarang ini Ni Ketut Astuti tidak patah semangat, walaupun dihadapkan pada kenyataan yang sulit, Ni Ketut Astuti wajib membantu suaminya untuk memenuhi kebutuhan hidup keluarga sehari-hari dan juga membiayai kedua anaknya yang masih duduk di bangku pendidikan yaitu SMU dan SD. Bersama suaminya, Ni Ketut Astuti berusaha untuk mengembangkan usaha peternakan Penggemukan Babi yang selama ini sudah mereka jalani. Usaha ini sudah lama mereka jalani sekitar 10 tahun yang lalu dan sekarang ini dalam satu periode pemeliharaan mereka memelihara 4 ekor penggemukan yang akan di panen 5 bulan kemudian dengan keuntungan sekitar Rp. 800.000,- sd  Rp. 1.000.000,- dan usaha ini selalu dilakukan secara bertahap. Dalam menjalankan usahanya Ni Ketut Astuti mengaku sering kekurangan modal untuk membeli pakan. Dengan kemudahan yang didapat dari Dinari melalui pembinaan dan pinjaman Modal Usaha sebesar Rp. 5.000.000,- dengan jangka waktu pinjaman selama 6 bulan dan pembayarannya dilakukan setelah akhir periode Pemeliharaan maka Ni Ketut Astuti lebih bersemangat lagi untuk mengembangkan usahanya dan dia sangat yakin bahwa usahanya kedepan akan lebih baik sehingga ekonomi keluarganya juga bisa lebih baik.
texts.en:
Facing ever increasing economic challenges, Ni Ketut Astuti never loses her motivation. Ni Ketut Astuti needs to help her husband in fulfilling her family's need and pay for her children's primary and middle school tuition fees. With the help of her husband, Ni Ketut Astuti developed a pig fattening business that was started 10 years ago. Every 5 months growing cycle, they farm 4 pigs that are then slaughtered after 5 minths. However, recently, Ni Ketut Astuti is having troupbe paying for feeds. With DINARI's funding and technical help, she is seeking $600 loan with 6 months tenor to purchase feeds. She is very hopeful that this loan will help her gain more profit to help her improve her family's finances.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase feeds

loans.name: Mirela

texts.en: Mirela Mehanović was born in 1981. She comes from the little city of Gračanica, which is known as agricultural area. She is married and the mother of one son. Her husband works in a local company and he earn 700 KM. Mirela has a small orchard which produces apples and pears. She sells her products to small local shops and sometimes in the marketplace. Mirela needs some place to store her products and she will use a loan in the amount of 600 KM to build it. Her aspiration is to rent one orchard to sow and that way produce and sell more.

loans.use: To build a place to store products

loans.name: Ni Wayan Sumarni

texts.id: Bekerja sebagai seorang petani  dengan penghasilan yang pas-pasan membuat Ni Wayan Sumarni berpikir keras agar bisa membantu suaminya untuk memenuhi kebutuhan keluarganya yang semakin hari semakin meningkat. Ditambah lagi dengan harus membiayai keperluan sekolah 2 orang anaknya yang masih duduk di bangku pendidikan SMP dan SD. Setelah mendapat informasi tentang program DINARI yang disosialisasikan oleh pembina secara langsung, Wayan Sumarni memutuskan untuk meminjam modal ke DINARI untuk mengembangkan usaha ternak babinya yang sudah lama ia tekuni. Dengan pinjaman awal yang di dapat sebesar Rp.5.000.000,- dalam jangka waktu 6 bulan dan pembayaran dilakukan pada akhir periode pinjaman, Ni Wayan Sumarni menggunakannya untuk membeli bibit penggemukan dan sisanya akan digunakan untuk membeli pakan. Ni Wayan Sumarni berharap dengan pinjaman ini usahanya bisa lebih berkembang dan hasil yang didapat juga akan lebih meningkat dari keuntungan yang diperoleh sebelumnya Rp. 250.000.- per ekor setelah dipotong pelunasan pada akhir periode sehingga mampu mendongkrak ekonomi keluarganya.
texts.en:
As a farmer with limited income motivated Ni Wayan Sumarmi to find additional income stream to help her husband fulfill their family's needs. Furthermore, her 2 children are entering middle and grade schools respectively. After learning about DINARI, and obtaining technical help from the foundation, Wayan SUmarmi decided to obtain a $600 loan with 6 month tenor. Ni Wayan Sumarmi will use the funds to purchase piglets and feeds. Ni Wayan Sumarmi hopes that this loan will help her business expand and bring her more profit. She projects that she may obtain additional $30 profit per piglets after loan repayment. Therefore the additional profit may help her improve her family's finances.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase Piglets

loans.name: Zarqa

texts.en: Zarqa baji is the wife of M. H..  She lives in an area named Bund Road in Lahore, Pakistan. She has been living in this area for the last 10 years. She is the mother of five children: three sons and two daughters. Her elder daughter completed her 10th standard in school; the younger is in 5th standard. Her youngest son is in kindergarten. Zarqa baji's husband has his own garment shop in a market named Chandni Chowk. He has been in this profession for the last 20 years. His elder sons help him in his business. Zarqa baji is a homemaker and prefers to do household work. She successfully repaid her two previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more garments to expand her husband's garment business.

loans.use: To buy more garments to resell

loans.name: Ni Wayan Ganti

texts.id:
Kehidupan keluarga Ni Wayan Ganti dan suaminya sangat sederhana, suaminya yang bekerja sebagai seorang petani terkadang penghasilannya tidak mencukupi kebutuhan hidup sehari-hari mereka. Hal ini yang medorong Ni Wayan Ganti sebagai seorang istri untuk membantu suaminya dengan beternak babi. Saat ini  Ni Wayan Ganti memelihara 1 ekor penggemukan dengan waktu pemeliharaan selama 6 bulan. Dalam satu periode pemeliharaan keuntung yang didapat Rp. 300.000,-. Selama menjalankan usahanya Ni Wayan Ganti mengaku sering kekurangan modal untuk membeli pakan dan pengobatan apabila babinya sakit. Melalui program DINARI, Ni Wayan Ganti mendapat pembinaan dan pinjaman modal usaha sebesar Rp. 5.000.000,- yang di pergunakan untuk membeli bibit peggemukan dan pakan untuk mengembangkan usahanya agar bisa meningkatkan penghasilan keluarganya.
Ni Wayan Ganti sangat berharap dengan mendapat pembinaan dari DINARI usahanya bisa lebih berkembang dan keuntungannya juga lebih meningkat dari sebelumnya. Ni Wayan Ganti juga sangat berterimakasih kepeda DINARI yang sudah memberikan kemudahan dengan memberi pinjaman modal usaha  selama 6 bulan yang akan dibayar pada akhir periode pinjaman.
texts.en:
Family life of Ni Wayan Ganti dan husband is simple, her husband works as a farmer, and sometimes his income is not sufficient to pay for their daily expenses. This pushed Ni Wayan Ganti as a wife to help her husband by raising pigs. At this time Ni Wayan Ganti raises 1 fattening piglet for 6 months. In one raising period, she could profit Rp. 300,000,-. (Translator’s note: 1 US$ fluctuates between Rp9,000-10,000.00). During the time of running her business Ni Wayan Ganti admits that often she lack capital to buy feed and medicine, especially if her pig is sick. Through DINARI program, Ni Wayan Ganti obtained development and loan of Rp. 5,000,000,- that was used to buy feedstock and feed to expand her business and increase family income. Ni Wayan Ganti very much hope that from DINARI development, her business could bloom, and profit also increase compared to before. Ni Wayan Ganti is also thankful to DINARI who gave simplicity by giving a loan that will be paid back at the end of the 6 month loan period..

Translated from Indonesian by Gwan Ang, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy piglets (Membeli anak babi)

loans.name: Advija

texts.en:
Advija Avdić is a 41-year-old women. She lives in a village named Donja Orahovica near Gračanica. Advija is divorced and she has a 13-year-old daughter.

Advija and her daughter have good organized lives. Her daughter goes to primary school and Advija is employed in an ambulance.
